headline: Great Culture, Incredible Team, Exciting Problems and Opportunity
pros:
Opportunity - high growth means you can excel if you perform well
Mentoring - work with people smarter than you, and a team that cares about your success.
Exciting Problems no matter the team.
cons: Its a fast paced environment. There is a bit of stress and pressure to deliver. focus is on short to mid term growth, sometimes at the expense of long term.

headline: Job Interviews
pros: The company seems fun to work for.
cons: The company has between startup and mature company mentality. Pays less than mature companies and retains that feel of startup feel...It is a good place to work if you are under 30 and this is your first job...If you are more experienced in the industry, the environment may come across as a bit strange for older folks...

headline: Qualtrics CSM
pros: Great people and culture, I enjoy coming to work
cons: Pay seems a bit low compared to peers

headline: Strong culture, not enough people
pros: They are very fixed in the culture and the ways things should be. Very smart and sharp coworkers.
cons: Never enough people to do the job. Hiring bar is way to high to ever get enough help on projects.

headline: Decent place to work
pros:
- Free lunches and stocked kitchen
- Cool and relaxed environment.  It's an open plan so if you like the noise, it's great.  If not, it's not the place for you.
- Co-workers are hard-working, smart and fun to hang around
cons:
- Transparency is talked about at the higher levels and it happens to an extent but not completely.
- Low pay because we know how much we're worth in the market.  They typically pay 10-20% below market so if you're looking to be valued, look elsewhere. 
- On the sales team, there's the boys club so you'll want to avoid that if you don't fit their mold
- HR seemed supportive in the interviewing process but I've seen candidates in general not get responses or weren't treated well.  It feels like that department is ok with burning bridges which is not a good representation of the company if most candidates interact with them.

headline: Great opportunity to start your career in sales
pros:
-Successful company that is doing really well right now. Lots of long-term growth opportunity.
-Transparency. Promotion path is very clear and the company prides itself on open information flow. Weekly company meetings (TGIT) gives everyone company updates.
-The people. Everyone who works here is incredibly intelligent and hard working. They do a great job of hiring the right people. You will have the chance to meet and network with a ton of people around your age which is super valuable especially if you are just starting off your career. Managers are there to help you succeed and are great leaders. The leadership here is amazing. Lots of people to learn from.
-Autonomy. No micromanagement at Qualtrics, at least in sales.
-The culture. Catered meals 4 days a week, snacks on deck, coffee and coke machine. Wear whatever you want. Massage chairs, Gym, basketball court, longboards.
cons:
-As an SDR your a lot of your success can be tied to which AE you cover
-The location. This is something people need to be aware of if they are coming out of state. The office is located in Provo which is a heavily populated LDS Mormon area. Be prepared for a culture shock. No bars, tight nit cliquey community, not your ideal place to live if you are a twenty-something college grad. If you want to live in SLC or Park City it is quite the commute but Qualtrics accommodates with Frontrunner passes or a shuttle if you live in PC. Still, if you take the frontrunner be prepared for an hour and 20-minute commute every day. Not ideal.
-Like everyone else has been saying the pay isn't great. Gotta respect their business model though, its obviously working pretty well.

headline: Account Executive
pros:
You will have amazing opportunities to learn from a very skilled management team. 

Company is very transparent, and voices are heard.
cons: Often times the career paths can be limited, and unless you have a certain goal in mind, it can be easy to spin your wheels in the same place.

headline: Going Places - You get what you put in.
pros:
- Quickly growing company with lots of opportunity
- Ownership of projects if you're an engineer
- Solid mentorship
- 'Transparency'
- Good cultural values
- Good work life/balance
- Everyone's super friendly
cons:
- No transparency at all with regards to RSUs.
- Not a lot of transparency with regards with feature and product development.
- No transparency with regards to how sales are down, but not really relevant for engineers.
- Although claims to be an engineering and sales driven company, at times the latter can feel more important.
- As with any company, there are office politics at play.
- Seattle office is overcrowded.

headline: Starter Job
pros:
-Free food (catered lunch 3x a week)
-Laid back atmosphere, including dress
-Beautiful campus
-Good benefits
cons:
Once you advance a couple levels, opportunities for advancement are scarce. Salary is ok, but not great comparable to similar companies. VERY much a "bro" culture, especially in sales. And if you are not in sales, you are pretty much considered a support role to sales, as they are the moneymakers and anyone else is second class. They plug Transparancy at every turn, yet upper management is not very transparent about decisions that affect many employees, like the timing of the IPO. 

The open floor plan may be a benefit to some, but as an introvert I often found it distracting and overwhelming. 

This is a good place to build a year or two of business experience out of college, but not a place to build a career.

headline: It's a fun place!
pros:
- Great work culture
- Management really cares about employees
- Very helpful in developing each team members skills
cons: - It was a little too large of a corporate structure for me. I was employed during an expansion period so the promotions and accounts were more select. (personal preference)

headline: Great Atmosphere, Not so great pay
pros: There is a lot of fun stuff to do there, and the people are great. If you're a product specialist, you have a lot of choices for where to go in the company too.
cons: Pay is not as good as other companies. They make up for it with catered food, a gym, and basketball court though.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good culture -- well organized, fun to work there, great products, lots of cool new projects
cons: Big company. Engineers are also responsible for production assets so you have to be on-call for a week every month or so which can either be a breeze or pretty time-consuming and annoying depending on what team you're on.

headline: Great company
pros: Good benefits and fantastic location
cons: company not as known in EMEA as it is in the US

headline: Excellent Company Culture
pros:
- Laid back, yet productive environment
- Great office with lots of perks
- Solid product with potential for growth
- Transparent company culture and leadership
cons:
- Low pay
- Location in Provo, Utah
- Not as many opportunities to move up, but I imagine this will change because the company is growing at a rapid rate and things will eventually change

headline: Better than most
pros: Flexibility is pretty good. Pay is comparable with roles at other companies.
cons: Culture can seem contrived at times. Sales team is very green.

headline: Great company
pros:
Fulfilling job
great ambiance
Free food
Friendly coworkers
Ability to move up quickly if you perform well
you learn a LOT
catered lunches three times a week
cons:
salary is a bit low
some of the problems stem from the software
growing pains of a startup

headline: Love it!
pros:
- Great environment in the engineering department. 
- Within my first couple weeks, I was contributing to my team's product.  They trust new employees to get started right away.
- Pay is pretty competitive, especially considering the low cost of living in Utah
cons: - Career paths aren't clearly defined (management is working on improving this)

headline: It's a starter job
pros:
Great people
Food is nice
Vertical potential
cons: Works you to the bone

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work, awesome perks
cons: Pay isn't incredible, tough to move from dept to dept.

headline: Smart People, Good Experience, Low Pay
pros: Everyone is smart.  They do a great job of hiring.  Even most on the support team went to great schools (BYU, Michigan, etc).  Very relaxed environment.
cons: Low pay, very religious area

headline: Fun, High Stress, Low Pay
pros: Fun environment. Lots of room for growth. Most employees move up in the company within a year.
cons: Exclusionary culture, arrogant coworkers, high stress although better than any other call center

headline: Account Executive
pros: The company offers great benefits alongside great work conditions, and the colleagues are very friendly. There is a dynamic social hub, and a lot of events are organised. The product is outstanding.
cons: The European management team has a lot of room for improvement. There is no personal development for AE, and the management only cares about numbers on Salesforce. People are leaving the company every week due to the pressure from the management team.

headline: Great company
pros: Its a very fast paced environment and gives a lot of opportunity to shine in your area of expertise. People are great, everyone is talented and hard working yet humble and scrappy. Great place to start your career as it teaches your work ethic and gives a lot of boost to your career ladder.
cons: Has some growing pains in expanding teams and growing internally but the upper management is addressing them very well.

headline: AR Specialist
pros: The culture at Qualtrics is amazing!  It is so open and friendly and innovative.  I feel like I am really able to make a difference in the company and I feel so comfortable talking openly with my manager.  The people are great and everyone is willing to help you succeed!
cons: The free food will make you gain weight, so you'll need to join a gym.

headline: Great software company
pros: All the engineers are brilliant. Work and life balance is incredible. Quarterly bonuses. 3% 401k contribution completely vested.
cons: No tuition reimbursement for higher education. I feel like this is important if you want your engineers to gain those skills, and many other tech companies do this. Also, the company culture can tend to be obsessed with sales numbers. But engineering culture is great.

headline: Endless career growth opportunities
pros:
General: 
-Access to leadership, including the executive team, is unparalleled anywhere, particularly a company of this size and growth rate. “Transparent” value of the company really rings true here.
-Company is hitting financial goals that most companies in the Bay and Utah alike wouldn't even be able to imagine, making for an exciting exit in the future
-The growth of the newer lines of business and sectors is mirroring that of Qualtrics' initial "rocket-ship" expansion, with momentum only growing stronger each month.
-Great benefits/401k plan
-Huge engineering push in the past year (with opening of Seattle) will allow for quicker innovation timeline
-Work along very smart people (many Ivy League/top school grads), and everyone in Utah is incredibly kind

Client Success:
-Particularly in Client Success (but also in other divisions), managers encourage you to find areas for improvement and empower you to implement solutions, both within and beyond the scope of your team
-The ability to collaborate cross-functionally is a huge plus, as it gives you a great strategic/360 view of the company allows you to work with Sales, Engineering, Support, Marketing, etc. 
-CSMs get to have a high impact with Fortune 500 brands
-Fast personal growth due to level of responsibility, the stakes of the clients, purview of role

Overall, the careers opportunities both within your division and outside of it are there for the taking, as the promotion statistics are pretty astounding. I also relocated from a large city to work at Qualtrics, and the transition has been great.
cons:
- Engineers don’t give frequent enough updates regarding development timelines and projects
- If you’re not already raising a family, you’ll likely want to live outside of Provo. While the company provides options to accommodate, you have to commute if you want to live in Salt Lake City or Park City

headline: Qualtrics Company Review
pros: Fantastic benefits, great management, awesome perks
cons: So much food, you will gain weight

headline: Sales
pros:
The leadership cares about its employees, and they care about taking good care of their customers.

The company is growing at a very fast rate, so there are a lot of opportunities to learn, collaborate, and advance within the company if you are hard working.
cons: I would say the pay structure could be a little more competitive, and the average ramping time for sales is a little long.

headline: Qualtrics is a great place for a software engineer
pros: Can quickly be involved in high impact work. Flat organizational hierarchy, easy to talk with anyone. People care about your opinions.
cons: Pop machine isn't always full :)

headline: Sales Operations
pros:
- Unique growth plans meaning your career options are endless. A very exciting place to be.
 - Culture is great fun, a vibe I have yet to see in my career to-date. 
 - People are bright and driven but don't take themselves too seriously.
 - Chance to write history.
cons: - Not for the faint hearted or people who need structure and certainty.

headline: Growing company. Need more leadership, better compensation
pros: Coworkers. Smart, scrappy, fun people who will be successful in life. Benefits are good, new headquarter building will be beautiful. Open floor and collaborative spaces. Dogs come with you to work. Company is rocketing. You will be smarter here just by sitting around these people.
cons:
Think twice before betting your career on Qualtrics. A good starting point, but not looking like a great long term choice. 

Qualtrics does a good job of selling the idea of joining a rocket ship during meteoric rise. Problem is, not a lot of employees benefit from the rocket ship. Leadership is hired from everywhere else. So when a recruiter talks to you about internal opportunities of a rocket ship, don't buy into it. Revenue is rocketing, but the company is frugal and does what it can to not spend more on employees. I exclude benefits, which get better each year. Don't expect much pay or opportunity to advance from within. This is really true for experienced hires. Salary never increases.

Client Success is changing too. Management has made it clear that we have to prove our value to the company by expansion (aka selling more products). It feels more and more like we have a quota, just like sales. It is a bad place to be when you feel like you need to prove your worth to your own company all the time. This is a downer part of the culture.

Management in Client Success are managers not leaders in any definition. Managers are so focused on numbers (renewals and opportunities) and take no time to lead the team in any way. It's no surprise given the pressure of the company to prove our worth, but I've never seen any other division where there is zilch investment in the wellbeing, career development or coaching of the team they work for. It's utterly maddening. Career progression and development are an afterthought at best. It is like the opposite of LinkedIn or other employee first companies out there.

There is a sad ceiling to your career in Client Success at Qualtrics. Career path is a concern that is voiced by in this group, but nothing real has been done to address it. The concern is always brought up in town halls and in other glass door reviews, but management just doesn't get it. One or two slots for team lead positions does not settle the concern we all have, that there is hardly any chance of big career milestones in this group. One of the selling points of this group was that it would grow quickly and leadership positions would come along the way. Well we've only grown a tiny bit and hardly any new opportunities have been offered. A bad over sell of what this team was supposed to be.

I think to myself if Client Success managers realize the delicate situation they are in. We are a talented group of guys and girls with good education and experience. Opportunities are out there, and the status quo will not keep everyone around forever. We are so stretched thin now, if half has many people leave as are open to other jobs, our books are going to suffer. I believe management thinks it is tougher to exit than it really is. The Smiths and a few others will receive life changing $ in an IPO. The rest of us will get a scrap, but that's far less valuable than making the right career choices in the long run. Before joining remember that all stock units are gone if you leave before the IPO.

headline: Sales Company, Not so great for non-sales employees.
pros:
- Fun office place
- Good co-workers
- Free food office perks
- Potential to become a valuable company
cons:
- Sales first company
- Support/ClientSuccess/Engineering work long hours and don't get much for it
- Management is hit and miss. 
- Don't promote much from within
- They dangle stock and the IPO but it never happens
- The employee stock pool is smaller than your average tech company
- Promotion process seems to be all about knowing the right people
- No raises
- Dogs. They can be fun but they also smell, some bite, and they make messes in the office.

headline: Sell your Soul to Qualtrics!
pros: Fun environment, usually good coworkers
cons: Not paid for overtime, expected to work from home constantly, overall you're not appreciated unless your the top performer

headline: Decent company, nothing particularly inspiring
pros:
-Qualtrics knows how to party 
-A lot of pretending to be a tech start up (ping pong tables for example), but those things are still fun 
-Benefits package is very strong 
-New building will be really nice for Provo employees
cons:
-No flexibility in working arrangements, you have to be in the office
-Micro management
-Not transparent (what happened to radical candor?)
-What IPO?
-Dogs everywhere
-No career advancement
-Buggy products
-General lack of opportunity
-Salary: low to begin with, never grows

headline: Work with Customers (non Sales)
pros: Exciting to work at a place where trajectory is up. Revenue continues to increase at surprising rate. Growth oriented. Open atmosphere. Charismatic CEO.
cons:
Others have mentioned it, I agree: if you're not in Sales, you are 2nd tier employees at Qualtrics. 

That's tough enough by itself, but realize that Qualtrics is not an employee friendly company. Company would counter that with its benefits package (which is decent), but culture is so much more important. Day to day life is dictated by culture, and Qualtrics culture is not employee friendly. Company is divisive, judgmental and employees are first to blame if something goes wrong. It's hard to be happy and work hard when you feel like you have to constantly watch over your shoulder. Never worked in an environment so implicitly threatening to employees before coming here. 

One of Qualtrics claims is that employees bet on Qualtrics and Qualtrics bets on them. Never seen something so patently one sided. Qualtrics culture is that you bet on Qualtrics, give your life to Qualtrics, or you're out the door. Would be nice if Qualtrics actually backed up its claim and focused more on employees.

This is not a 9-5 job. Technically, it's an 8-5 job, but if you're only here from 8-5 then you are under performing and won't be here long. 

Promotions are so rare and company constantly hires management from the outside. Again, see point about not being employee friendly. Don't think that you're special and will come in and outperform everyone. These are smart, hard working people and most get passed over for external hires. 

Because of the above, I know many feel like they are now in a dead end and need to look at other companies to move forward in their career.

Wages only increase with promotion. See above on how difficult that is. Lose to inflation, quality of life suffers. 

Company claims to be transparent, but grievances or complaints will be met with hostility and possibly worse.

IPO never seems to happen. It's dangled in front of us as motivation, but seems like it will never come.

Managers are extreme micro-managers. Does not feel like the freedom or autonomy we were promised.

headline: Worst decision of my life coming to Qualtrics.
pros:
-Technology: The technology is pretty cutting edge and at the forefront of feedback collection and marketing research. Research Suite is great, but the other tools (especially SI) needs to be built out and updated.

-Co workers (some): Had some really interesting and good colleagues during my time at Qualtrics.

-Company parties: Pretty amazing and well organized parties.
cons:
Since day 3 on the job, I hated if for the 20 or so months that I was there. In Opportunity Development, all you do is cold call. Bonuses depend on how many set meetings get accepted by your Account Executive, so some OpDev reps will have AE's who cheat and accept meeting that aren't good or even happened. Those OpDev reps are praised and quotas for everyone are in turn raised.

When you become an AE yourself, you will have zip code territories with mostly very small businesses who 1) can’t afford Qualtrics, 2) have no or little need for it, and 3) have no idea how to do research (e.g., it’s an onion farm). It’s extremely hard to sell as a new AE and most fail. There is a huge retention problem regarding AE’s, but the leadership insists that’s it’s not a problem.

-Pay: You are grossly underpaid at Qualtrics. Unless you have been in sales for forever and have large accounts, you will not be living large. My family even qualified for food stamps and Medicaid because the pay was so bad.

-Leadership: If you are LDS, imagine the worst, most number hungry zone leaders; those are the sales leaders at Qualtrics. Leadership mostly hangs out by themselves and don't do a good job of coaching or assisting people on their teams. Pep talks consist of sports analogies (Michael Jordan missed this many shots and kept going...flu game...etc.) At one point they even motivated us to be "All In" and tried to motive us with the story of how Cortez burned his own ships while committing genocide against the Native Americans. 

-Bro mentality: Too many bro's and Provo All Stars; showing up to work in flat brim hats and basketball shorts. The CEO also does his best to be a bro.

-Transparency: In the interview and recruiting process, they proudly say that all employees are owners and have restricted stock units. In reality, those units aren't worth anything. Only the founders and some top executives have shares that are actually worth anything. If you are looking at Qualtrics, don't even think about the potential stock options, because it's of no value, and definitely not worth taking a 20% pay cut for. The CMO and VP of Engineering all left suddenly while I was there, and we were told bogus reasons explaining why they left. If they really want to be as transparent as they say they are, talk about why the VP of Engineering left in the middle of the biggest product launch in the company’s history. 

-No internal mobility: Something that was promised during recruiting was the opportunity to join other teams within Qualtrics. This isn’t true. Maybe five years ago, but if you are in sales, you are stuck in sales. No internal mobility at all.

headline: Great Potential, Lack of Vision
pros: Free snacks are always a plus no matter where you work. You just can't beat a company that knows humans are its driving force and they need food to stay energized. The other benefits of 100% paid healthcare premiums, company 401k contribution, stock options (though it is still unclear when the company will go public), company parties and the open office enviornment make it a really solid company to work for. Having free access to the product is also nice!
cons:
Unfortunately to me, the cons are really difficult to look past. 

PRODUCT:
The features of the product are great, but the slow functionality, lack of design and poor engineering efforts cause every department to suffer. Poor engineering direction (I have heard from multiple engineers that feel as though they are fixing a sinking ship) has caused the product to become slow, laggy and functionality to break often. Sales team seems to oversell the product leaving us Client Success Managers or Implementation Consultants with the task of cleaning up the mess. We reach out to engineering to fix key elements of the product, but things end up getting pushed back quarter after quarter. The engineering team seems to have a pile of bureaucracy slathered with a bit of a god complex that make it slightly messy and unorganized.

SALARY:
The salary is just... terrible. It doesn't matter what role you are in (except the sales elites), the salary is a lot less than other companies in the tech industry of Utah. It's sad that the engineering team gets paid as little as they are taking into consideration the level of effort day in and day out with the product. It is baffling to me that a unicorn company valued at over 1 billion dollars pays its employees some of the lowest salaries. The sales team is regarded as the companies heart and get paid good base salaries and bomb commission. Sales teams are definitely important, but if you need your sales team to be your heart, your product just might suck too much. It would be nice to see people that have to keep the client happy and the product pumping paid a bit more.

MANAGEMENT:
Within Client Success, at times it feels like a bunch of high end business school snobs that are slightly two-faced at times and often lead by fear. They tell us to come talk to them about issues or concerns, but then don't seem to follow through with what is discussed. They are focused more on numbers than clients (partially due to the sinking ship issue), and don't seem to know how to help train and mentor us to reach future career goals.

headline: Good place to work for a couple of years
pros:
- Fairly laid back work environment (You work hard but it's pretty chill - shorts and sandals are the norm in the summer).
- You are surrounded by very talented and driven professionals. They only accept top people from top universities so the connections you make are pretty great.
- Qualtrics is growing really fast right now which means that there are more opportunities for early career growth than at most companies.
- You will likely get opportunities to do projects that actually matter and make a difference for the company.
- Free food / ability to bring your dog to work if that's your thing.
- Definite emphasis on continuing education. Qualtrics University has licenses to Pluralsight and Code School that you can use.
- Most managers really care about developing you and helping you move up in your career. (This isn't necessarily the case outside of Global Operations)
- You'll make friends that you'll actually want to keep in touch with in 10+ years.
- 3% match without the match (they just give you 3% into a 401K, no strings attached).
- Pretty good insurance benefits for full time employees.
- Stock options (vested over 4 years and only valid if you stay through an IPO or acquisition).
cons:
- Qualtrics University is a call center. You may be doing projects and working with people from top schools and household name companies, but at the end of the day you will be answering support phone calls and emails for a year before you can move into another position.
- Salary for entry level positions outside of engineering are typically in the mid 30's with little to no room for negotiation. After hitting certain criteria which take about a year, you are able to get a ~$10k raise.
- Qualtrics touts transparency, but there is little transparency into compensation or promotions. It's taboo to talk about comp at work.
- The software products Qualtrics offers are surprisingly buggy. 
- Rather than pay off technical debt, Qualtrics loves to create new features and products so everything they build feels half finished.
- If you get hired, that means you are way overqualified for the position that they are giving you and you will probably need to work for a year or more to get into a role more suited to your abilities.
- Qualtrics won't help pay for grad school, MBAs or otherwise.
- There is a definite air of elitism (Qualtrics upper management really thinks that Qualtrics is the best tech company in the world and look down on other tech companies).
- The word meritocracy gets thrown around a lot, but tenure is a much better indicator of promotion then work preformed is. If you do your job, stay late once in while (making sure that your manager knows about it), toe the line, and don't ruffle too many feathers you should do pretty well.

headline: Opp Development Rep
pros: You work with great people. Definitely a work hard, play hard mentality. Great culture. This position is good if you have no experience in sales...Qualtrics gets their ODR's quickly up to speed on the initial part of the sales cycle.
cons: A LOT of cold calling. Your job is to set up meetings for Account Executives. It can be tough because if the AE doesn't feel like the meeting is worth their time that can effect your monthly bonus.

headline: Product Specliast
pros: Quarterly bonus , young work force and free pub for Friday nights. It is good to be part of a successful organization that is growing rapidly. The hiring bar is quite high so the workforce tend to be quite intelligent. The amount you need to learn at the start of the job can seem quite daunting at first but once you ramp it gets a lot easier.
cons: Management has lost interest in its employees of late and do not take feedback very well. The work put into this job is not really rewarded by praise , incentives ( excluding cash ) or career progression.

headline: Exciting market, Great technology
pros: In sales, you're  exposed to great managers and an opportunity to make quick money in an exciting  emerging market solution.
cons: Some questionable moves made in sales operations (it seems the experience here is not up to scratch compared with other organizations of similar growth trajectories).

headline: Dream Job
pros: This is a company that has huge projections for disrupting an entire industry. They have a very nurturing culture and wonderful benefits. I really appreciated the trusting culture. I expected to come in a be at the top but found that everyone around me was trying for the same and this really helped me to accelerate.
cons: can't complain, I feel fortunate to work here.

headline: Intern
pros: Great company culture, people are friendly and hardworking. You can tell the company cares about its employees and their success. You can get good feedback on your work, as an intern I was given projects without much supervision which was great to be in charge of my own work to an extent. The people in my department were really nice, they were all friends, and I always felt included despite being part time. It's really a great environment, but also full of people who take their work seriously and love their job.
cons: Open floor plan made it hard for me to focus at first, I focus better in a quiet setting so that took some getting used to. Because I was part time communication wasn't always the best as far as being in the know on what was going on, but that's an easy fix, you just have to initiate a little more communication.

headline: Decent SaaS company
pros: Dogs in the office, free snacks and drinks.  Good benefits
cons: High workload, training isn't great.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Company invests in people, continues to grow
cons: Pretty standard growing pains -- growth is better than the alternative though, so can't complain too much

headline: Qualtrics is tough but good
pros: Opportunity and freedom - As it is a very fast growing company, you quickly have to become good as you will be tomorrow's leader or 'experienced' team member, where tomorrow is literally within 8-10 months. With this comes huge opportunity (if you want it) to develop and learn. As the company needs to change regularly because of it's ever changing size you become the process creators of the future. Management tend to trust the people they promote will do a good job of creating the future of the company.
cons: Qualtrics is a hard place to work. The company re-invents itself every 18months and requires you to evolve with it. This can be a strain if you want to have a comfortable job that requires you to do a similar thing day in, day out. Because it is hard work, it can be easy to feel you are not being paid enough at the beginning. This is a fallacy in my opinion. Also, pay gets considerably better with promotion.

headline: Great company to bet on ... willing to bet on employees
pros:
Qualtrics is growing very quickly and that creates lots of opportunities. People who work well in ambiguous environments, who are proactive and innovative, and who take initiative do very well here. There are some who watch more from the sidelines and wonder why they don't get the same opportunities. My experience has been that if you have a good idea, can make a business case for it and are willing to do the work, then Qualtrics is willing to bet on you and give you as much opportunity as you're willing to take on. In other words, it's not just a growing company, but a company that wants you to grow with it and all the opportunities are there for the people who want them.

The culture is also really good. Qualtrics is very thoughtful about its growth and works hard to make sure it keeps what is good about the culture and is always improving in areas where things can get better (they added full payment of healthcare benefits for the employee and their families one year, they added 401K matching the next year, etc. etc.)
cons: There are constant growing pains. Qualtrics is good at figuring out how to address them, but that doesn't mean that they aren't there. It is a very loyal culture, which can be both good and bad.

headline: Stepping stone
pros: Been here awhile now and there are some great things. The benefits are above average, especially medical. Food is always stocked, and you dont find that everywhere. Company meetings have a lot of energy and spark the drive for a day or two. Then back to sad life
cons:
I'm in client success and it is a dreary grind. We are focused on numbers and numbers and numbers. Performance is measured so close, and then you have to outperform in the next quarter. Goals are not based on any logic, just 25 to 50% more than what you did the quarter before. Its tiring and makes you forget why you're supposed to be here, for the customer. 
Managers in client success micromanage and use fear tactics. We are not led or inspired in any way, just managed and managed. There is a lot of talent in this group, but I personally know many are waiting for the next opportunity either inside or elsewhere. Managers may be smart but are emotionally unintelligent. No one feels like anyone cares about the employees at all just numbers. A lot has changed here in the past year and not in a good way. This job is not fun or rewarding at all

headline: Sales
pros: The people you work with are extremely intelligent and hard working.  They usually come from a strong academic background.  Qualtrics does a good job of hiring people that are natural problem solvers.
cons: Ryan Smith and leadership will do well, the company as a whole will do well but they have saturated the market.  They really pitch an auto-promotion within your sales career but they really limit your resources making it harder and harder to hit your OTE.  The ones that are single, or have very little expenses are hoping they can just wait it out and put together a couple good quarters to get promoted while the ones with a family have a hard time of making ends meet in this sales job.

headline: The Best People
pros:
Amazing teams: It has a healthy, open culture that works hard to integrate each new team member. 
Liberty: Qualtrics provides each persons the opportunity to design their own work schedule and style and really forge their own path.
Accountability: People look out for each other here, or at least that's been my experience. When a manager gets a promotion, they give due credit to the team that got them there. If someone is struggling, someone else will step in and help without needing to be asked. It's a good environment to learn in.
The food: there's always food at Qualtrics.
cons: The open air quality takes some getting used to, as sometimes it's hard to focus when people around you are being loud. The compensation, while adequate and competitive, do not stand out in any particular way. I feel like I need to work out more because I eat so much here. Honestly, I've had few complaints so far.

headline: Exciting company!
pros:
- Incredible growth
- Fun, casual, and comfortable work environment (Free food, soda machines, massage chairs, golf carts, no offices in the building, beautiful view, & dogs aloud at work)
- Great benefits (Free health insurance, 401k contribution of 3% from the company no matter if you contribute or not, and RSU's (Restricted Stock Units)
cons:
- Salary (Little low, but is made up with benefits offered and work/life balance)
- Location (Headquarters in is Utah, unlike most tech companies that reside in Silicon Valley)

headline: Good place to work, but far from perfect
pros:
Good people: Qualtrics does a good job of maintaining a high bar for talent, so you're bound to meet and interact with a lot of really smart, cool people. It's a great place to learn and pick the brains of bright people.

Good benefits & perks: Free snacks are really nice to have. It's also a fun environment with shuffleboard, ping pong, etc. available to play. Also their zero premium health insurance and HSA plans are fantastic.

Good product: Qualtrics is a great product and truly a leader in the industry. It's easy to get behind and believe in the technology.
cons:
Low pay: Unless you're an upper level leader or top sales person, Qualtrics pays about 10-20% below the market rate. This can be frustrating as an employee. Promotions outside of sales are very difficult and slow, despite what may be communicated. If you are starting in an entry level position, don't count on ever getting a real big pay day (again, unless you're a sales all-star). From what I understand they do this is in order to be more profitable to get a higher valuation when they IPO. Also they don't want employees who work there "for the money", but rather people who believe in the vision and want to be there for other reasons.

Hype to substance ratio: There's a LOT of hype from leadership around Qualtrics' future, how they're profitable, how they're a rocket ship, how they going to IPO, how they have amazing investors and a great board, etc. but much of the hype seems to be just hype and regular employees don't necessarily see the benefits of the company's "deep pockets" or unicorn-ness.

Politics: Most employees at Qualtrics are ambitious and young in their career and are striving to climb the ladder and move to the top. Unfortunately this leads to quite a bit of politics and ulterior motives. Lots of people trying to do whatever it takes to get recognized by the right people and lots of the time it's about who you can get tight with within the company and not always a meritocracy. Overall employees aren't treated as well as they should be and certainly aren't treated as the company's most valuable asset (unless you're a top salesperson).

headline: Glad to be gone
pros:
+ Nice office, but not a great location for commuters
+ Open floors; flat (no offices)
+ Health benefits are great
+ Good coworkers; nice pool of talent and usually fun to be around
cons:
- Low salary
- Culture; company feels like it's out to get its employees; little to no loyalty; employees never feel like a top concern
- Qualtrics hires all of its managers from outside; almost no upward trajectory
- Middle managers are terrible; no passion, no leadership, all management. Culture of micro management is creeping in on the back of 'performance' measurement
- Best way to get noticed is to sit at your desk from 7am-7pm
- Constant state of transition/repair in products

headline: Sales Europe
pros:
-Incredible Co Workers
-Great Office location  
-Really Interesting Solution
cons:
Ridiculous Metrics & Targets 
Complete market acquisition mode- no brand awareness  
More cold calls is managements  answer to all problems

headline: Ready to get out of here
pros: Beautiful location at foot of mountains. Half hour drive to Sundance and skiing. Love all the pups running around the office. Good teammates. Medical benefits are pretty good.
cons: I have a hard time dragging myself to work every day. I thought it would be a fun, dynamic atmosphere, welcoming to all ideas. Not the case. If you're not a senior manager, your ideas will stall or get trampled. Really strange because I thought this would be a strength at Qualtrics. The only thing we seem to care about here is number of dollars coming through the door. Employees are not valued here. Vacation time is limited. Salary is bogus.

headline: opportunity development
pros: great culture and staff. great opportunity to make a career.
cons: low salary, not many vacation days

headline: Great experience
pros: The people are incredible. Younger environment, but the energy is invigorating. The company is continually innovating as it grows, so there are always new exciting initiatives.
cons: General pains of a quickly growing company. Career trajectory was not always clear, as my team was newer.

headline: Client Success
pros: This is a great entry-level job destination. Flexible environment with quite a few perks (stocked kitchens, ping pong and pool tables, quarterly activities, decent PTO, etc). The parties thrown and the swag given out compares to none. The energy in the office is good and the people extremely friendly. Company values are emphasized.
cons:
Two things: (1) no opportunities for career growth and (2) client success management is terrible. 

Despite the promises of career advancement and opportunities for growth, I found that there are very little indeed. In aggregate, Qualtrics does a poor job promoting within (aside from tech support) and consistently funnels in talent from outside to fill management positions. There are those who have been with Qualtrics for years and are genuine leaders in the company that are getting passed up for opportunities consistently. There is no upward trajectory. 

Management in Client Success do not lead, train, or contribute in meaningful ways. They play favorites, lead by fear, and offer very little value in constructively inspiring a team or offering legitimate assistance when needed which is very demoralizing. They are not true leaders, but glorified babysitters that can make life seemingly unbearable at times.

headline: Mediocre company at best, steer clear
pros: Massive sales machine. Open office concept. Relatively flat hierarchy, but absentee leadership. Take your dog and kids to work if you want. Most of my coworkers were pretty decent people.
cons:
Employees are disposable means to an end for this company. Every other company i've worked for treats it's employees better than Qualtrics. The main reason I left.

I've worked for a handful of tech companies, and the culture at Qualtrics is terrible. Political and definitely not merit-based. Sales is slightly different because it's easy to measure performance, but problems are widespread everywhere else.

Products are the buggiest I've sold. Company hired a lot of engineers recently, so the problem will get worse then will probably get better if they know what they're doing.

The culture probably seems so terrible because leadership tries to make such a big deal about how good the culture is, while everyone is so tired of it. 

There are three types of employees at Qualtrics: the 8-10 who will make good $ from the IPO, 90% who are demoralized but can't leave because if they do they lose all their equity, and the smart ones who are walking out the door. 

Almost everyone I knew at Qualtrics was tired and hoping to leave asap. Save yourself the trouble. Also, I agree with the guy who wrote about the fake reviews - it's simple to see which reviews are real and those that are fake.

headline: Some good with the bad, mostly BAD
pros: Company hangs its hat on providing food during company meetings. You can also pay $2 on Tuesdays to get lunch. You can also fatten yourself on all the candy that floats around the place. 3 treadmill desks. 7-8 massage chairs, 4 are in working condition. That's about it.
cons:
- Like everyone else on Glassdoor says, the pay is terrible. Stagnant.
- IPO is always "around the corner" but never happens, and you can't take stock units with you if you leave. You're stuck
- Leadership is in an ivory tower. Definitely a boy's club feel. Good 'ol boys.
- Male dominated
- No employee is worth anything unless you're in the Sales org
- Culture is "so important" but only to outsiders; on the inside it has nothing to do with the company MO

headline: Incredible Opportunity to Launch Career
pros: Incredible Executive Leadership. This is a great place to sharpen your skills as a young professional.
cons: Few. Mainly the lack of recruiting outside of the area. They are doing a better job, but it's difficult to have diversity when hiring from the surrounding university of students who all grew up in the area.

headline: Good benefits - limited opportunity
pros: in terms of perks, benefits, and overall culture, Qualtrics is a great place to work.  They pay health insurance premiums and dental is cheap - they also have a generous 401k donation regardless of whether or not you donate yourself.  Company parties are great and the people are generally pretty cool.  Lots of free snacks, food, and drinks.
cons: There's some politics involved in the promotion process from opportunity development to account executive.  The top reps who have been in sales at Qualtrics for years have all the vast majority of the good accounts, making it hard for a new reps to hit quota.   A little less than 40% of reps hit quota, many of them go entire quarters without making a single sale.  They don't pay their employees enough, which is made evident by the fact that they are in a constant struggle to attract software engineers (which they desperately need more of).

headline: Meh
pros: Great holiday parties. Uh-ma-zing. Seriously, the best. Energetic CEO. I eat cereal for free every single day.
cons:
Where do I begin? It can't be overstated how poorly Qualtrics pays its employees, even for Utah. I guess all that money went to the holiday parties (see above). Not only does Q not pay its employees, it doesn't value them much at all. I've had two great coworkers laid off in the past few months for no reason at all. They were great people and good performers. Clients loved them too. Worse yet, the layoff was a complete surprise to them - everyone knows that good leaders don't let someone go by surprise. It should have been on their radar through performance reviews, but it wasn't. Completely demoralizing to the group.
Client Success is a terrible team to be on. New management of this team care only about adding to the bottom line. We are more salespeople than trusted advisers. We work for managers, not leaders. There is no excitement here, only quotas and performance reviews. No career advancing - it is literally a dead end for me. I wish I had never come.
Sales people are gods at Qualtrics, and everyone else supports them. Even Legal, or Finance, who hold fancy degrees, play second or third fiddle to the high school GED Provo-allstar who met his quota this quarter. It's exhausting. Avoid it. Not a happy place to be.

headline: Catfished - over hyped company
pros: Open environment. Lot of food. Company sells its products well; efficient sales force. Decent benefits (health care). Pretty good coworkers. Lot of job growth in 2015; essentially halted in 2016.
cons:
Most companies probably do this, but its obvious that Qualtrics is gaming Glassdoor with false positive reviews. I've worked here for years and its so easy to pick out the super peppy, happy reviews of Qualtrics. No real employees feel that way about the company. Any review that has Cons filled with "growing pains" or "young company" or "lack of direction, but open opportunities" is masking real life at this Qualtrics. This is my honest review. 

- Poor compensation
- Little PTO... compare to local companies like Adobe
- Not as much opportunity as company would have you believe
- NO RAISES without "level" promotion, which are extremely rare even for high performers
- Sales obsessed, not customer obsessed
- Face time (being at the desk from 7:30-6:30) MATTERS here; its cultural and its real
- Middle management is terrible compared to other companies I've worked for
- No tech company feel anymore; completely operationalized and feels like a dull corporation
- Dogs everywhere; making noise and making messes on the floor. Its disgusting

Avoid Qualtrics. The company is doing well financially, but is not what it says it is. Qualtrics does well because of its obsessive focus on sales. Sales rules all. Company is not customer-obsessed, but is sales-obsessed. Company also touts being 'transparent' but that doesn't seem to apply to leadership. 

Talk with employees of the company ... almost no one is happy here. The company will likely do well for another year or two, squeezing every last drop of ambition and goodwill of talented employees; but that well will run dry and you will see massive attrition. There is no payoff from the hard work and demands of the job.

headline: A Hidden Gem!
pros:
* Transparency: open environment. Everyone can look into what the CEO and leadership did last week and is doing this week (or quarter). Your position doesn't limit what you can or can't do. The competent is rewarded more than the confident.
* Scalability: this is not your typical startup. We have a huge load on our system. We are getting really challenged to scale our system to the number of our customers and their customers.
* Ecosystem: Like it or not, we are going to become the ecosystem for getting insights about customers, employees, and the market. As of today, everyone in education knows about it. In a few years, everyone in business will be in the same position. 
* Everyone is talented and HUMBLE. Yes, humble. Good luck finding that elsewhere. I'm going beyond humble now because I want to showcase this hidden gem. 
* We took the best habits of Google, Amazon and Microsoft. All the other bad habits like working on random stuff just for advertising, abusing our workforce, or nourishing slackers, we left them behind :)

Disclaimer: these are my own thoughts; not Qualtrics'. I'm giving you my anonymous opinion as a Qualtrics employee here in Seattle.
cons:
* Health insurance is not that great (compare to Microsoft). Still, I don't have to pay for it like I did in past startups!!
* If you're here to slack and relax, this is not the right place for you.
* If you just care about what you're doing and don't think of the customer, it won't work either. 

Come super prepared, the interview bar is high, as an engineer and as a human being.

headline: Great for entry-level
pros: The open floor plan, free food, and abundance of young talent make Qualtrics a dream for young professionals looking to get their foot in the door in tech/startups. It's a very relaxed work environment and you can wear jeans every day. Strives to be similar to the culture in Silicon Valley.
cons: Very few processes in place (It's a young startup), lots of competition and credit-grabbing, and politics. The open floor plan became distracting at times, and it felt like I couldn't get promotions without working 80 hour weeks. In addition, the pay is poor in comparison with other companies but Qualtrics seems to think the experience of working there is worth it in itself. Everyone is on email at all hours of the night and expects you to be, too.

headline: Account exec
pros: A lot of potential for the company
cons: Closing business can be very challenging

headline: Good place to work
pros: Room to grow, can make an impact, great people to work with, freedom to work
cons: I was paid very under market for a long time because they sell you on the "opportunity"...I am hoping it will be worth it

headline: Sales
pros: Best-in-class technology helping organizations solve challenging problems.  The people who work at Qualtrics are, generally speaking, incredibly smart and dedicated.  In sales, you control your own destiny here - be successful, get promoted.  Great career opportunities across the organization.
cons: Typical growing pains.  Silos lead to communication gaps, which can be troublesome at times.  Leadership is pretty aware of it though, and do make an effort to minimize that.  But it is still there.

headline: Cool company.
pros: Great place to work. Given the amount of growth there is never a lack of things to do.
cons: Continue to invest in your people and don't believe that high growth will keep people around. Pay is fairly low given the high expectations.

headline: Sales
pros: Qualtrics is a fantastic company with great products, great people and a superb culture. We work hard but I love it. This is such an exciting company
cons: No cons - one comment - this is an acquisition business - if you are looking for an exciting sales role Qualtrics is the place to be - but you need to be strong on the acquisition sales side.

headline: Product Analyst
pros: If you want a great company culture this is the place to work. Qualtrics is both a workplace and a fun place with people who all share the "work hard, play hard mentality.
cons: The company in general is young, including its management and the CEO. This makes it difficult, at times, to get solid mentorship opportunities as a newer employee. Many there are still just figuring things out.

headline: Opportunity Development
pros: Great culture, enjoyable team and office, promotion opportunities
cons: Typical promotion politics.  Op-Dev can be a grind.

headline: Product Specialist
pros: Great atmosphere with peers, easygoing and great people make up for the pros of the company. It is very transparent company with regards to department communication and overall results. Growing rapidly, room for maneuver and career progression.
cons: Rapidly expanding and career progression getting more strict in processes. Very metrics oriented in the specific department, everything is metrics and relies in metrics that not always will give qualitative data towards how good a person is at their job or how much would they be suited for a more responsibility role. Management starting to clash with the easygoing culture.

headline: Almost Silicon Valley-esk.. but with difficulties
pros:
Best reasons... some of the people are really talented.
Some of the best salesmen on earth
Sales based, the whole company is sales
Utah is interesting, ambitious culture
Such good snacks
Unique culture
They are turning a profit, they are the big name here in Utah, 
one of the biggest home grown companies out of utah,
valued a few billion dollars
cons:
I felt like the leaders there were compensating for not making their high school football team
They are elitests, and now have a "my way is the only that works, bro" attitude
They dont allow you to really explore methods that work
The best can fly under the radar doing what actually works
The mediocre have to use the proven methods, eliminating growth for themselves & company
^^^^ is poor leadership they hurt themselves.
Must do exactly what they say, your talents are void if you dont

headline: Opportunity Development
pros: Seems like the company is moving in a good direction.  High growth, big sales emphasis.
cons: My role is particularly a grind, but you have to "put in your time" and then you can progress.

headline: Great company
pros: Great work environment and culture.  It is a laid back but competitive at the same time atmosphere. The company is a rocketship that is going places and with that growth provides lots of opportunities to grow your own career.
cons: Best time to join would have been a year or two ago, but still a great time before they go public.

headline: Marketing
pros: Great place to work, and surrounded with smart people.
cons: Compensation is average, but they make it up in the benefits.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Wonderful working atmosphere, great people who are excited to be there, wonderful perks, such as massage chairs, free food, company parties, plus more for full-time employees
cons: If you don't like pets, beware, people always bring their pets to work. I was fine with it, but not everyone cares for that aspect. Currently very client focused, but may become too separated from client

headline: Silicon Valley in Utah Valley
pros: Energetic, intense, autonomy, free food, great benefits, sense of growth
cons: High pressure, pay is on the low end, process above people

headline: Account executive
pros:
-great culture
-amazing benefits
-fantastic leaders/founders 
-trajectory (company is absolutely killing it)
-great product 
-unbiased sales promotions
-competitive compensation
-massage chairs
-company is actually profitable unlike other tech companies (in Utah or Silicon Valley)
cons:
Difficult for new reps to ramp up.
Many of tenured reps have the best accounts
Typical growing pains like constant change in accounts, territories, etc.
Expect to make a lot of phone calls as you ramp (100+per day)
Difficult to coordinate with other teams to sell larger enterprise deals.

headline: Sales
pros: Great team of people to work with. Not your typical sales environment.
cons: Ridiculous metrics and targets in complete market acquisition mode. OTE is very hard to achieve, and very little autonomy to decide how to operate your daily job.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Free food, Growing company, Healthcare benefits, Culture,
cons: Clear favoritism - low salaries

headline: Great Learning Experience
pros: Great environment, great perks like food and massage chairs, and really smart people to work with.
cons: I didn't get paid a lot, but I've heard that intern wages have gone up.

headline: Account Development
pros: Great culture and awesome perks
cons: Low pay and no paternity leave

headline: I like it here
pros: Great opportunities.  I feel that I can trust management to take care of their employees.
cons: Hasn't been growing nearly as fast as we want.  A lot more work to do then engineers to do it.

headline: Great tech company. Expect to work a lot though.
pros: Above average benefits, free food.
cons: Salary employees can expect long hours.

headline: Amazing Company
pros:
- Incredible culture
- Fabulous leaders
- Great Product
- CEO is super chill
cons: - Qualtrics is a premium product, it is often difficult to sell against similar freemium services

headline: Play hard; work harder
pros:
* Development teams have a lot of flexibility in the technologies they use
* Moving to a MicroServices architecture - it's working!
* Agile methodologies are the way of life
* They try hard to build a good product
* The engineers are smart and good to work with
* Culture is fresh and fun - lots of parties and activities, food, fancy workplace
* Benefits are great (although paid leave is pretty skinny)
cons:
* While they want quality software, they often don't invest in the development infrastructure necessary for it to happen
* The fast pace and high pressure tends to burns out engineers
* The vast majority of engineers are just starting out in their careers, they could use some more experienced people
* Management doesn't really know what to do with senior-level individual contributors
* Good work can be unappreciated when it's not on sexy stuff
* Having each dev team be responsible for their services running in production encourages the building of robust software, but when a small team has to babysit hundreds of servers day and night, development falls behind
* Engineers often work evenings and weekends to meet goals (usually from home)
* Being on-call is sometimes brutal. It's no fun getting awakened in the middle of the night because a disk somewhere is more than 80% full.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Best place to work, great perks, pay, and culture
cons: I have no cons to share

headline: Implementation Consultant
pros:
- Very autonomous & challenging
- Great chances to work cross-functionally with Sales, Engineering & Marketing
- Awesome client relationship development
- Good opportunity to develop skills and become invaluable
cons:
- Still ironing out processes that cause headaches for us sometimes
- Often working with demanding clients
- Not a super clear path to career development within the Q

headline: Glass Walls to Distract From Glass Ceilings
pros: Qualtrics has an energetic, yet relaxed environment.  The company itself has a lot of momentum.  I made very good friends while working there, and I ate a lot of free food.
cons: They definitely roped me in with the flashy culture and free stuff, but it became clear pretty early on that this is not a place you want to stay if you want to have a very successful career.  They start you at $35k-$50k depending on your position, and you'll do some climbing from there, but not much.  All while you see executives show up in decked out BMWs and Land Rovers.  Like several others, I personally heard some of the higher-ups brag to their visiting friends about how little they have to pay their employees.  This place can be a great feather in the cap of a young college graduate, but if they want to keep quality employees, salary should be more competitive and there should definitely be more upward mobility rather than hiring management externally.

headline: Great Company
pros:
-Start up culture, young, fast pace
-Gain lots of experience quick, take an idea and get it done
-Benefits are free for the whole family
-Amazing perks/ freebies
cons: Qualtrics really is an awesome place to work.  There is not much bad to say about it.  The pay is on the lower side and it is hard to find a parking spot.

headline: Great place to start a career
pros:
1. The Work. Even as an intern or entry-level employee, you won't be doing menial work. You will immediately be placed on projects that have an impact on the company, and early on you can earn a lot of responsibility. The company really rewards people who work hard, so if you're willing to work hard on exciting projects, this place is for you. 
2. The Culture and People. During my time at Qualtrics I did not meet one single unfriendly person. On a professional level, all the people I encountered were more than willing to collaborate on projects, give feedback, answer questions, and provide guidance and mentorship. On a personal level, the people are an absolute blast to work with and your managers care about how you feel about your work and how you are doing.
3. Perks. Company shuttles from Park City and Salt Lake City, employee appreciation events and parties, free food in the office, being able to bring your dog to work, a cool office space, and an overall fun culture make this a fun place to work. 
4. Utah. Utah is absolutely beautiful in all seasons, and there is always something new to do, whether that's discovering a new bar in SLC, a new national park, or checking out a music or film festival.
cons: The only downside is that unless you're Mormon or have friends/family in Provo, it might not be the ideal place to live. However, if you're willing to commute from the surrounding areas (and SLC and Park City both have company-sponsored transportation to accommodate this), then this isn't an issue.

headline: Great Company
pros: The company is growing very quickly and is being very successful in the market. The executives recognize this and are always considering the wellfare and livelihood of employees first when it comes to re-investing this success back into the company.
cons: I have no qualms with this company.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Designate your own schedule and typically not micro managed but my manager was.
cons: Managers are promoted on a buddy to buddy basis. Some managers are sexist.

headline: Amazing Company
pros: Qualtrics has a great, upbeat culture that makes you want to come to work. People are friendly and there are plenty of places to go to reset your mind so you're not stuck at your desk all day. They really try to take care of their employees and their are all kinds of perks.
cons: This isn't necessarily a downside, but it is highly competitive. Everyone that works here wants to do their best and be the best so it makes for a  competitive environment. The one real downside to working at qualtrics is that the bathrooms are always full and it's near impossible to find an open stall.

headline: Great company - poor compensation
pros: Everyone is working together to help move the needle for Qualtrics. Everyone is motivated and hard working. A lot of the managers and leaders are invested in the employee's development.
cons: Pay. One of the lowest salaries for the industry. Commission (sales) and bonuses are nice but taxes take a lot of that. If you want to bring in and keep top talent pay more.

headline: Not ideal
pros: Nice selection of free food, gym, fun toys, people are pretty friendly, benefits package is great—all great distractions to the big problems.
cons: Employees are underpaid, very conservative/religious workplace, Provo is a boring/vanilla city, management is disconnected, raises and promotions are scarce, total lack of process in how things are handled, decision-making is laughable, CEO is full of crap.

headline: Opportunity Development
pros: Great vibe, culture, and people. Focused on hiring the best and that has been beneficial for the rate at which they are growing. Scaling and so there are some growing pains, but great company to start your career.
cons: Not really a con, depends on type of employee you are, but the culture has a way of making you feel comfortable with little progress. You will grow in the direction management wants you to grow, not necessarily the direction you would like.

headline: Great place to work while in schpol
pros: free food every Friday, free lunch everyday of the last two weeks of every quarter, open environment, nice cereal bar
cons: they offer little paid time off. No paternity leave.  Internal promotions seems to be rare. Great place to work fresh out of school, I don't know that I'd want to be working here in 20 years

headline: Qualtrics
pros: Fully stocked Kitchen, Pool table, games consoles, clever co-workers
cons: Career path is ambiguous due to how fast its growing,

headline: Product Specialist
pros: We're relocating to a more spacious office space.
cons: Low pay, pretty bad location. There is nothing around Provo.

headline: Client Success Manager
pros: Love the benefits package. 100% covered health care premiums and they contribute to a 401k regardless of employee contribution
cons: As with any startup, the career paths are still being developed.

headline: Outstanding...Challenging...Energetic...Intelligent!
pros:
An engaging environment that empowers individuals to achieve amazing things is probably my favorite part of Qualtrics.  The company is growing quickly and there are lot of hard problems to solve.  I love being able to work shoulder to shoulder with brilliant people who are passionate about making research simple.

I love that most people who are at Qualtrics did not necessarily chase the highest offer, but instead chased the offer with the most to offer (mentorship, environment, professional challenge and upside).

The benefits are pretty amazing too.  I feel like most companies are trying to find ways to give less while Qualtrics does the opposite.  My impression is the Qualtrics is continually finding new ways to reward its employees.

Also, just to mention a few of the benefits that are pretty incredible:
Health Benefits 100% paid for
401K contribution by company
Holiday company shut down
Good bonus upside for top performers
Every FT employee an owner
Amazing parties
Awesome environment
cons: Because of the rapid growth the company is always changing.  You need to be someone who can embrace change otherwise you may not like it.

headline: Sales
pros: Free food (cereal, trail mix, bananas..), fun atmosphere, educated group of people, transparent office, Apple computers.
cons:
Long work hours. My team supervisor would always tell me that they expect new hires to work 10 hour days for the first year or so while they gain clients. The problem is that most of the big-name clients are already taken (and the remaining clients don't really have a use for the product or can't afford it). There is no room for growth and it's very difficult to switch departments. Their biggest department is the sales team and if that isn't a good fit for you, good luck trying to interview for another position. 

Additionally, the base salary is super low - $30k. Not enough to live off of while you gain clientele. 

The upper management is trying to be like Google and most of them are extremely full of themselves.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great company to work for.
cons: To many people wanting to be a boss!

headline: Very challenging, very rewarding.
pros:
Culture: is among the most overused terms in business today but Qualtrics has what companies aspire to. Yes, there is free food and basketball hoops but that is an aesthetic and has nothing to do with real culture.  People work insanely hard and are laser focused on company, team and individual success - but without taking ourselves too seriously. Laughter is a constant sound throughout every day. 

Career path and velocity are unrivaled.  While most entry positions aren't the very best you'll find, ability to move up and up and up from an entry level position IS THE VERY BEST YOU'LL FIND. Most entry level employees are EXPECTED to be promoted two if not three times in their first 18 months. 

Absolute expectation of excellence. I've been in meetings where most would be celebrating success and we were running a postmortem to determine why we "failed" - as in you get a 98% on the hardest course your school offers and your immediate reaction is to deep dive on why you didn't get 100%.  

Said differently "Good enough at Qualtrics literally means not good enough."
cons:
In any hyper-growth environment, everything is constantly in flux - you must be able to deal with a small but constant degree of disfunction. For those that enjoy optimization and problem solving, this is  your dream. For those that want 100% stability and consistency and cannot tolerate even a small degree of change, this place is your nightmare. 

Level of competition internally is too tough for most... with a ~5% hire rate Qualtrics is one of the most talented collection of professionals anywhere, meaning some that are used to being top 10% are simply not going to be top 10% at Qualtrics.  It is a put up or shut up environment.

headline: Enterprise business developement
pros: Qualtrics has a good atmosphere and driven people.
cons: You have to like talking to people on the phone to excel at this job!

headline: Fast paced vibrant company
pros: Growing rapidly, great people and ongoing hiring , solid company values, open and transparent culture, so much opportunity ahead as growth continues
cons: Sometimes it seems we are trying to do too much at once and it puts a big strain on resources and work life balance

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great environment with people who truly care about you.
cons: Growing company with a lot of growing pains. Pay is below average and you will work harder at Qualtrics than anywhere else.

headline: Sales Management
pros: Qualtrics has a great company Culture.   The company is growing very fast and therefore there is a great opportunity for personal and career growth.    Solid solutions that are market changing.   Be part of building something new in Dublin.
cons: it is hard work driving into new markets but that is part of the fun in building new European business.  if you are into hunting and driving new business then this could be for you....if not I would look elsewhere.

headline: Poorly managed, cheap company. CEO disengaging from employees
pros: Fun atmosphere meant to distract you from other issues. Lots of broken toys around the office. Blaring pop music in front office so that you think the company is "cool." Company feeds you food from the pantries. New office should be nice. Everyone gets stock in company, but it won't be worth much to 98% of employees.
cons:
Pay - it's terrible. THERE ARE NO ANNUAL RAISES, which means with inflation you will actually earn less each year. Are you serious? Yes. Raises come only with "level" promotions, which are different than role promotions. Level promotions are very rare, in spite of the fast growth and what you will hear from recruiters. This is by design - the company is cheap ("frugal") and intentionally underpays its employee base. There is a small cap on how many can be promoted in each division - even if all members are high performers. This really stifles motivation after a year or two. 

CEO - removed from employees. Ryan used to conduct company meetings, but we haven't seen him in a couple of months. Company likes to brag about how he sits on the floor at a regular desk like the rest of us, but never mention that he actually works in a different building near his house in a private office. Not exactly the "employees' CEO" we are lead to believe. 

Management - misguided. Smart people, but have no previous experience in startup software. The company is changing in a bad way. The primary focus of management is on maximizing sales, rather than on the company's most valuable resource: employees. This is going to bite. 

Location - Provo. Come on.

Transparency - poor. Really insulting given this is one of the company's core principles. 

So many dogs running around the office. It's like a zoo now. If you are allergic, stay clear of this office.

headline: Fun company, laid back atmosphere
pros: Laid back office, free food, big name clients.
cons: The culture can be a little loud at times.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Fast Paced environment. Get to work with a number of great companies from all over the globe. Opportunity for growth are clearly defined. (At least within sales)
cons: Culture of transparency and "scrappiness" is starting to erode with such fast growth. Bureaucracy is starting to take root (1,000 employees)

headline: Qualtrics is Amazing
pros: Working with intelligent people on interesting projects. Great culture, good benefits.
cons: Lots and lots and lots of growing pains. They're growing so fast that they can't keep up with themselves. Some of my favorite coworkers quit because they were underpaid and under-appreciated.

headline: Product Specialist Position Review
pros: Great, energetic atmosphere. High quality co-workers. Awesome fringe benefits: meals, snacks, swag, company parties, massage chairs, etc. The healthcare benefits are also pretty competitive.
cons: Low pay. They leverage the fact that people want to stay in Provo to allow them to seriously underpay over-qualified people. In the recruitment process, they preach "endless opportunities for career growth in such a fast-growing company." In reality, however, unless you have a strong background in development, your options for vertical movement within the company are extremely limited.

headline: Great company
pros: The executive team really has your back. They want the very best for their employees.
cons: Sometimes feels like you can't move up within the company.

headline: Review
pros: There are good perks and great people in the office
cons: The workload can be suffocating

headline: I enjoyed Qualtrics.
pros: Great company with fun atmosphere.
cons: Not much room for growth.

headline: Amazing company!
pros:
Young, enthusiastic workforce
Potential to make great friends
Autonomy
Free food...SO MUCH free food.
Dog-friendly
cons:
Leadership unorganized
Not as "transparent" as they advertise

headline: A motivating place to work!
pros:
Employees at Qualtrics are motivated and full of energy. It is inspiring to work along side them.
There is a lot of opportunity for growth at Qualtrics. Managers are very committed to your growth and improvement.
I love working with the new hires to train them and welcome them. It is great to have a job that makes people feel at easy on an day that is often scary.
cons: There is not a lot of time for training. I have been trained mostly on-the-go. This is exciting though and I love being challenged. I prefer it this way than to a slower paced job. There is no room for complacency in this position.

headline: Amazing company
pros: Transparency, great products, tons of opportunity for growth.
cons: Growing pains that are typical and come with a fast moving tech company.

headline: Good Engineering Culture
pros: The engineers at Qualtrics are smart. I can only speak to the Provo location, but I had a very good experience overall. Many of the people I met either came from the Valley to be near family or would have been good engineers in the Valley had they been located there instead.
cons:
As an out-of-towner there was a bit of culture shock living in Provo, and I found the office to be the only place where I didn't feel out of place. I also got the impression that some of the engineers there would have liked to move around the company more – that is, switch teams every year or two to get exposure to different technologies and mix things up. 

Also, the office is full of junk food. I ended up bringing my own food because everything was so sugary.

headline: Special Ops
pros: Qualtrics embraces creativity, thinking, and innovation. This is a cutting-edge culture--I've never had a more stimulating corporate experience!
cons: This isn't a con, but you must be motivated and self-driven.

headline: Incredible company
pros:
- Great benefits
- Friendly coworkers
- Very entrepreneurial environment (let you take responsibility for your own work and be independent)
cons: The starting salary is a little low compared to the average salary, but it doesn't take long to build your salary through commissions

headline: Love It!
pros: Qualtrics is a great company. They have amazing products and really care about their customers and their employees. They do what it takes to win. If you give to Qualtrics, you will be rewarded. If you are simply there to take, you will starve. It is a system based on meritocracy. There is great transparency. There is a great work-life balance. People that work here are amazing, fun, unique, nice, and honest. CEO/Founder is top notch - not what you'd expect from a thriving company, but he really cares and is passionate about the company and its employees.
cons: Compensation is fair, but you will need to prove yourself. There is no room for moochers.

headline: Great Opportunity
