pros: Collaborative environment but still with plenty of ownership.  Growing fast (demand is exceeding manpower),  Actively tries to follow strong leadership principles and organizational structure set by predecessors like Google, Facebook, and Amazon (main principle is "transparency").  Smart people and real engineering problems. "Startup" with much less risk than your everyday startup.  Lots of innovation and horizontal mobility.  Catered lunches 3x a week and occasional outings.
cons: There's a substantial difference between the cultures and degree of diversity at the different offices.  Not a "con," per say, but I'd do some research to figure out which location best fits your personality and lifestyle.  Stock options will improve post-IPO.

headline: Account Exec
pros: Work freedom. company culture, and company benefits & resources. We adopt a work hard play hard rule. Definitely the funnest office I worked in.
cons: Limited opportunities, leads flow to only certain individuals, so if you are in you will make a lot of money. Success is not always rewarded to those that work hard. I know many people that work 60+ hour weeks but make less than a newbie that comes in for a month and lands a big account or an inbound lead.

headline: Best company to work for in Utah
pros:
+Huge amounts of ownership/autonomy in projects
+Great, accessible leadership team 
+Crazy smart co-workers
+"Startup" feel and mentality (quick promotions, scrappy problem solving, new teams emerging)
+Feel valued as an employee
+Ice cream
cons: -If you like having very specific direction, probably not the company for you. The company expects you to find the best solution/vision.

headline: Sales
pros: Great place to work, great environment
cons: no cons really, you have to work hard to make it

headline: Client Success
pros: Fun office - great culture and people
cons: Pay was horrible, but I heard base salaries have been increased

headline: Not impressed, not as advertised. Poor leadership. Buggy products make life miserable for client facing employees
pros: Fun atmosphere. Generally nice people to work with. Great medical benefits. The company provides a lot of t-shirts. The company also stocks pantries with food, though it's mostly junk food. Impressive seasonal parties. CEO is inspirational and a natural leader.
cons:
Horrendous career paths. Not defined in any way and upward movement is rare. Lateral mobility is also difficult.
Severely lacking leadership at virtually all levels. 
Schizophrenic attention of upper management leads to terrible execution throughout. 
Culture is so-so, destructive in some cases. Lots of games, toys to project a Silicon Valley feel, but they are mostly superficial gimmicks. 
Products are unusually buggy. Much of life at Qualtrics is spent managing fires.
Upper management has little apparent vision for its teams. Occasionally, the supreme executive wand waves to divert all attention to the latest hot topic and disrupt all momentum. A huge productivity drain and short-sited. Kills morale, hurts clients. Seemingly no trust in the employees that had to pass such a "high bar" to get hired.
Company is intent on staying in Provo for some reason, despite the huge benefit to its employee base of moving to a more central location.
Way too many systemic problems to IPO in the near future. 
Has potential, but may have peaked. Probably not what is self-proclaimed: a unicorn.

headline: Gritty, hard, marathon...not a sprint. Requires mental stamina. Cold calling all day... Literally all day.
pros: Culture, coworkers, swag, work ethic, benefits, technology, products. Fast-paced, sexy tech atmosphere. State of art software (both selling and using).
cons: Original reps have all the 'brand name' accounts which are constantly producing for them and their quarterly quotas. They are in a great spot. The rest of sales are calling linen, manufacturing, trucking, grocery, and no name companies that don't really have market research, VoC, or Customer Experience teams, or budgets for Q's relatively expensive products. Tough to consistently hit quotas when prospecting these types of companies.

headline: Great Environment and Coworkers, Mediocre Management
pros:
My coworkers were some of the smartest people I know.  There probably wasn't a day on the job that I didn't learn something new. 


Qualtrics is usually great at adopting new technologies, you often work on the cutting edge. Qualtrics isn't afraid to tackle hard problems. I was excited to go to work each day.


The company seems to genuinely care about their employees. Free swag, office dogs, free food, Summer/Winter company parties, discounts to local businesses are just some of the perks Qualtrics offers. The health benefits are amazing.


At a high level, Qualtrics is very transparent. You will be aware of company-wide initiatives and goals. There is a weekly company-wide meeting where each department gives an update on their goals.


Qualtrics is growing at an amazing pace,  it gives you an opportunity to really be part of something awesome.


Being vocal about your opinions is encouraged, one of the "Leadership Principles" is Disagree and Commit. If you have the data to back you up, your ideas can flourish at Qualtrics. 


Overall, my experience at Qualtrics was very rewarding.
cons:
While transparency is one of the company's "Leadership Principles" it is often only exhibited at a higher, company-wide level. Lower level decisions were often made with employees told last minute. I often felt out of the loop as far as the path Engineering was taking. 


Management in Engineering often exhibits knee-jerk reactions. Be prepared to be pulled off of a project mid-quarter, or put into a "Code Yellow" which forces the entire team to work on a single issue, even when only certain people of that team have the skills necessary to work on that issue.  Decisions made by management are often emotionally or historically based, so have data ready to back you up in these situations. 


This goes along with the fast growth of the company, but be prepared to change teams. I was personally on three different teams in 2 years at Qualtrics. Also, deadlines are often imposed on certain teams or projects but these deadlines are often not communicated to other teams through management.


The high-bar for hiring is definitely an important part of what makes your coworkers great, but sometimes amazing candidates were not considered simply because their GPA was not high enough or they didn't have a degree. If you're not a buddy with someone in upper management, you likely won't get hired if your GPA is lower than a 3.6 or you didn't graduate from college. Several amazing, heavily experienced people were turned away solely based on these figures.  These can be useful metrics but are not the sole indicator of someone's success. The hiring process in general is not transparent and also hurts current employees who are stretched thin as it is and could really use more people on their team.


In my case, even after two years as a part-timer at Qualtrics, I was told I would not be hired on full-time based mostly on my GPA. Even worse, Qualtrics waited until the very same day I graduated from college to notify me of this. In the end Qualtrics can decide who they want to hire or not, but at least have the decency to do so in a timely manner.


Management is often disconnected from the day-to-day goings on of the company. Even team level managers are often kept too busy to be able to fulfill their management duties at the team level. 


There are bi-annual performance reviews which can be extremely helpful in receiving feedback from your peers and your manager. However, this is often the only feedback you receive. Managers are supposed to meet individually with each employee at least once a month but these were often cancelled because we were simply too busy. Feedback every six months is not truly actionable and processes need to be put in place to enforce more regular opportunities for feedback.

headline: Graphic Designer
pros: Working at qualtrics is great. I have freedom to be creative and work on fun projects. Great flexibility with scheduling and vacation. Amazing health benefits, they pay your premium.
cons: Not enough designers to cover the work load. Can get very busy!

headline: Qualtrics Dublin
pros: Office location is great and there is a bar on the top floor of the office. You get lots of swag.
cons:
This is not a cool startup, there is no room for individuality. Do it the Qualtrics way or move on. 

Micromanagement
Little or no coaching or support
Lacking in leadership
Unattainable targets

Stay away

headline: Great company with some considerable drawbacks
pros: Great atmosphere and fun people. Constant changes!
cons: Low base salary. Additionally, time off is less than ideal and takes a while to accumulate

headline: Sales
pros: Killer App. Dedicated Management. Awesome culture.  Great People.
cons: Not for everyone.  If you are not smart, driven, & tough, go look for an easier & less rewarding pop.

headline: The Place to Work In Provo
pros: You feel like you were really own the products that you work on. You get to deal with some really awesome technologies and are given a lot of freedom on how you want to work with them.
cons: It can definitely be stressful sometimes, and being on call is never very fun. It would also be nice to have more paid time off or more salary.

headline: Qualtrics
pros: We work as one big team,everyone is very supportive and more than willing to provide advice and share best practices so your constantly learning and improving your skills.As a result the culture of the company is a very fun and energetic environment with plenty of social activities and events in which we can all get involved and enjoy.
cons: Due to the fast paced nature and rapid growth of the organisation there is a need for continuous improvement and rapid learning which at times can seem like a lot to take in.

headline: Amazing company, culture, coworkers, and opportunities
pros: I work with amazing people everyday who are ambitious and excited about their careers. I love the opportunities that the "Q" has given me especially at an entry level. Anyone at Qualtrics, big or small can contribute to changes and ideas that influence the company.
cons: Some growing pains. Too big for our current building.

headline: Great people with some management disconnect
pros: Qualtrics has incredible people and for the most part hires really well. The perks, benefits and offices are well above standard and create a good environment to work. Some of the best sales talent and leadership you could find in any software company.
cons: Some senior management and the CEO/founder are disconnected from many aspects of the day to day business. While sales and support are strong, it has to make up for lack of investment in engineering on the user experience and design of the product. Marketing has never seemed to be understood at the company and the CEO has appointed inexperienced leadership with no marketing experience to the team. Outside of sales it is very hard to advance your career.

headline: Hyper-growth Start-up Atmosphere: Not for me
pros:
If your number one priority is career, Qualtrics is a great place for you to work. There are super interesting problems to solve. Qualtrics is doing amazing things in Engineering that very few (if any) other tech companies are even trying to tackle. 
The people you work with are super smart and you can learn a lot from them. The trajectory of the company is great, and it you can hang on to the 'rocket ship', I do believe that it's going places.
cons:
"Work hard, play hard" is the claimed motto, but the play hard part has kind of gone away in recent months, at least in Engineering. Engineers are generally expected to work crazy long hours, and on top of that, remain available all hours of the day/night/weekend in case of 'incidents'. Even when I wasn't at work, I couldn't relax. I was always worried about when the phone might ring. (If I could give work/life balance a 0 I probably would.) This wouldn't be so bad if the pay were near the top of the market, but it's not. It's middling at best. 
The culture has shifted in the last year or so. When I started a few years ago, everybody was pretty happy with the situation. Sure, things were still busy, but it was more driven by what we wanted to build rather than what we were told to build. It seems like the culture is shifting towards an Amazon style of Engineering department (based on what I've heard, anyway): employees are a resource to be consumed and discarded.
I'm hoping that management is just mostly unaware of the morale issues in Engineering. If they are aware, they're just ignoring the problem, which in a lot of ways is worse.

headline: opportunity development
pros: Amazing benefits, fun culture, employee engagement is very high, and promotions are based off of proformance.
cons: Young culture leads to unprofessionalism. Pay is less compared to other saas companies in the state. Poor location.

headline: Opportunity Development Representative
pros:
From day one at Qualtrics you will feel like you are part of a team and something very exciting. The training and support that we receive is excellent. You get 1-1 time with senior management. You can express ideas freely and openly. You are even asked to own great ideas when you come up with them so that you can make it happen. The road map to develop your career at Qualtrics is clearly outlined from day 1. It's up to you to work hard, it never goes unnoticed. 

From free lunch on a Friday to getting to help out at events. It's an amazing place if you want to have huge career.
cons: The job is not easy, but I think any job worth doing should be hard. You need to be self-motivated and driven to succeed. Some days you may have to work harder to hit your targets, but in the end you are always rewarded. Being organised is key to success at Qualtrics.

headline: Quni
pros: Fun environment and no take home work.
cons: It's a call center.   High burn out with core job.

headline: Product Support
pros: Qualtrics does a great job keeping the vision of the company with their weekly meetings.  The work environment is really nice and open and there is plenty of snacks to keep you happy throughout the day.  I enjoyed the people that I worked with there.
cons:
My perspective is that you stay in a lot of the roles longer than you should be there.  I felt like I saw people in OpDev and Support for extended periods of time when they should have moved up the ladder.  And the ladder for support is pretty short as you basically have two options of a Client Success type of role or Panels.  I chose to leave because I didn't feel I was growing anymore.  I felt that way after about 10 months of working there and stayed another 5 months after that and it didn't change, despite trying to convey some of that frustration.
At the time I was there, I know from the support team the most valuable people on the team did not feel that they were getting appreciated or bonused appropriately.  I sometimes heard from sales employees "Why can't we keep our best support individuals?"  I believe this has improved, however.
It also seems like it would be a hard place to work longer than 2 years unless you are an engineer or rockstar in sales. The hard thing with sales though is the cycle is so long you may take nearly a year to realize that the deals you thought you would have are not going to pan out.
I feel like they underpay at Qualtrics because they are able to keep most employees happy with the culture, snacks, etc.

headline: Sales
pros:
It is one of the best learning environments I have ever been in. People give sales a bad name but our job stays interesting every day because we are essentially a consultant helping solve difficult problems for the worlds most powerful companies!

The people are absolutely amazing, the company is growing fast, and the opportunities are unlimited. If you perform here, you can do whatever you want.

Really cool work perks too.
cons: It's a quota based position so if you don't perform you take work home with you every day. This can get very stressful. If you work hard it is pretty easy to stay on top of the game.

headline: Accountedge executive
pros: Nice environement where you can learn and grow really fast
cons: Work who can be repetitive

headline: Opportunity development
pros: Great schedule, an OK pay, great perks
cons: Not the best pay.

headline: Good but not great
pros:
Awesome culture
Really involved
Plenty of opportunities to grow
cons:
Not especially interesting work
Once in sales they never want you to leave

headline: Selective
pros: Qualtrics is easily one of the Utah business world's greatest success stories. Few companies have achieved the profitability, growth, and industry-changing accomplishments as the Q. Most companies pale in comparison in terms of excitement, energy, and smart, think-on-your-feet people. I would pit almost any Qualtrics employee against any other company's work-force and 9 times out of 10, Qualtricians would win. I love the people there and still consider some who continue to work there, very close friends.
cons:
Qualtrics attracts young, high energy,  and entrepreneurial people. Unfortunately, these people typically lack experience and therefore the savvy necessary to know when they've been taken for a ride. The sales side of the company can be lucrative, I admit - and Qualtrics will argue that their low salary, "high" commission model rewards those that "bet on themselves". The problem with that idea is that Qualtrics also has the responsibility to bet on its employees. The company takes absolutely no risk in hiring because its compensation is so low. Even if you are able to claw your way to high paying commissions, you have 1) spent at least 2-3 years getting there (years you could have been getting paid literally 3X the base salary plus double digit increases in commission at almost any other local company), 2) you would have done so working 60+ hour weeks with little to no real account management support and 3) you risk being put in a sub-par region and expected to hit the same quotas and as a result miss out on promotional opportunities that your peers who were lucky enough to be put in New York were able to get while you scratch out a living in Arkansas. 

Leadership will tell you my attitude is poor. They will talk about how difficult it was for them to get to where they are and promise similar opportunities for you in the future. The problem with that line of thinking is that their struggle resulted in major share percentages with massively high salaries. Very few, if any, people hired after the basement or "across from the practice field" days, will ascend to that level. Can you become a Regional Lead? You bet. But if you think you'll be allowed into the inner circle, you'll be sorely disappointed. 

I also found a great deal of frustration when it came to nepotism. When you run a billion dollar company, you no longer have the luxury to give hand-outs to your friends who you play basketball with on the weekends and give front row tickets to at BYU games. This is unprofessional, dishonest, and morally negligent. People should be rewarded on merit, not simply because they helped you win your church ball tournament with a killer J. 

If you want to run the company by working people for what equates to minimum wage, filling in the gaps with empty "benefits" like cereal, and promoting based on tenure rather than talent, that's fine. It's your company. Just have the balls to admit it. 

Don't put yourself in the same category as your employees. Most of them will never be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. They will, however, work just as hard as you. Yes, they will and do. I don't care how many private jets you take. And no, you didn't take a massive risk by starting this company. "Bootstrapping" for the Q equates to having a lot of family money that could be independently invested without real risk. When you start working a 60+ hour work week for a company that pays you a 36K salary and who tells you to "invest in yourself" to make a livable wage - when you do that for several years and simultaneously start a billion dollar company, then you can give yourself a pat on the back.

headline: Doesn't pay anything! I'm making 30% more elsewhere.
pros:
- Qualtrics has a great atmosphere and culture.  But offering snacks, massage chairs, and basketball hoops does not make up for the fact that they pay nothing. Even when you ask for a raise you are asked to "prove yourself" even if you've been there for years and have proven yourself already.
- Definitely have the best product out there.  It's the best survey platform, hands down.
- Lots of nice people. Lots of not nice people, too, but lots of nice people.
- Free healthcare, which is really generous.
cons:
- Lots of favoritism.  The CEO chooses his best friends for promotions even if they're hardly qualified. 
- Pay nothing. The hardest working people get paid the least, except for the engineers.
- Lots of flashy stuff to cover for the fact that their salaries are a joke.  I don't need cereal and free lunches. I need to get paid what I deserve.  
- If you don't work your 9 hours, people judge you for leaving early or getting in late (even when it's for justified reasons).  You don't have to work late or get there early, but if you don't, you get judged--even if you're doing your job and exceeding expectations.

headline: Great place to work and launch your career.
pros: The people at Qualtrics are great: smart people who are generally rowing in the same direction. People are fun, hard-working, and great to learn from. The food, games, events, health insurance, etc. are great. The product is awesome. The company is definitely going somewhere, and it is an exciting time to be there as you can help shape something amazing.
cons: I think that Qualtrics attracts the right people, but struggles to hold on to them. Base pay and bonus could be better, especially for people in non-sales roles. Qualtrics prides itself on being transparent but I feel that it could do much better in this.

headline: Great Culture, Exciting Business
pros: I'm surrounded by smart people every day, Qualtrics feeds me, we're given the ability and autonomy to do projects that will make a difference, the culture is extremely transparent so we always know what's going on and what our goals are, I can work from couches or massage chairs in the office, I can bring my dog and I can wear whatever I want!!!
cons: The pay is a tad low, but it's more than made up for in perks and the low cost of living here.

headline: Hypergrowth company, exciting atmosphere, opportunity for leadership, many good mentors, decent to great benefits
pros:
Challenging business problems.
Transparency to the max
Never bored.
Data driven decisions
Opportunity for leadership
Lots of freedom to build software the way it needs to be built
Good mentoring
High individual impact
Engineering is relatively close to the user
Culture
Team offsites
Weekly All hands meeting
People with good experience in leadership positions
High bar for hiring - everyone feels like they are working with people who are smarter than themselves
cons:
Fast paced
High expectations for delivering results
Bonus awarding system works but isn't as transparent as most other parts of the business

headline: Qualtrics has an energetic atmosphere which draws not only customers to also employees.
pros: They treat employees very well, and they make the atmosphere very lively and fun. From free food to swag, to out-of-this-world parties. Anyone would want to work at Qualtrics because of its transparent and hip culture.
cons: Just like any software company, engineering is crucial. I work for support and so often times I feel like I am on the tail end of endless system issues. Qualtrics is growing extremely fast and doing very well, but it seriously needs to do something to keep the product on edge and free from serious issues.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Work hard, play hard mentality. No micromanaging. Very transparent and collaborative environment. Very impressive caliber of employees all around.
cons: Not as competitive pay as it could be.

headline: Run from this company as fast as you can!
pros: Free food and drinks. All the cereal you can eat.
cons: Not the right place for large company people that have that in their background. If you are under the age of 25...stay. If you like to be micro managed....stay. If you want to be treated as a child...stay. If none of these apply...run as fast you can away from this company.

headline: Truly a fantastic place to work--I wouldn't pass this opportunity up!
pros:
Great culture.  Everyone is friendly here.  It's very flat....you don't get the sense that there are lots of politics and hierarchy; instead, it's all about what you get done.  The company is growing incredibly fast, so you get the chance to grow with it and move up as far as you want to go.  Lots of free food, free perks, great benefits, etc.  The HSA/FSA plan is awesome.  Great comp vs. the cost of living in Utah.  Extremely transparent.

I've worked at several companies, big and small, in and out of Utah.  Qualtrics is hands down the best I've been at.  I plan on being here a very long time.
cons: No offices--everyone is just out in the open in rows of desks (even the CEO), which is good and bad.  They go through growing pains from time to time as the headcount explodes.  You may feel lost in the shuffle during the recruiting process--don't take it personally, they recruiting team is just trying to stay afloat.

headline: An awesome place to work
pros:
- Meritocracy
- Great Culture
- Great People
- Dogs Welcome
- Hyper growth
- Opportunities to develop career
cons: - People can be passive aggressive

headline: Been at Qualtrics more than 3 years.
pros: You won't find a higher paying job in the valley if you perform.  There is no cap to salary.
cons: You will work your tail off....  (is that bad?)

headline: No place for women
pros:
Great product
Talented team
Typical tech office perks
cons: Zero women in leadership positions. Not one on the board. Not one in the C suite. Not even one in mid-level management. Unfortunately, many women have tried to step up and assume leadership roles only to be subtly undermined and disparaged until they quit. And in all cases replaced by men favored by the executive team. Opportunistic men are not only allowed to steamroll women and take credit for their ideas and hard work, they are rewarded and promoted for it. Not one woman has a place at the table where the big decisions and promotions are made. There is real conscious and subconscious bias that has led to the exclusion and alienation of women and reflects an inability of Qualtrics' leadership to work with and communicate with talented and capable women.

headline: Too much hype
pros:
Good benefits
nice office
Awesome Christmas party
As a company Qualtrics is relatively metrics driven
Lots of free food.
cons:
I personally heard one of higher ups boasting to a friend about how little they paid us while walking past my cubical.  I realize all companies want to pay people less, but that is a very disheartening thing to hear from your employer.  

Don't be sucked it by all the glitz and shiny toys.  Sure it sounds like a lot of fun to have a massage chairs, pool table, a gym, etc.  at work.  but if you are seen using any of these things during business hours (7:00am to 6:00pm) you will never get a promotion and if you are not hitting your quota you may get fired.   

While personally I thin some one playing pool during lunch who has not met their quota yet is sort of asking for it,  I also think it is dishonest for a company to give you these nice things at work and then get mad when you use them.  

When interviewing they will tell you that you will make it big at Qualtrics,  But the truth is the pay is crappy for every one who is not an engineer and they expect you to put in long hours.  

You  will need to work 60+ hours a week if you ever want a promotion.  Even if it only take you 40 to hit your quota.

headline: Astounding Company
pros: Great CEO, great coworkers, and a great atmosphere.  I haven't been with the company long but it has been absolutely amazing so far.  Everyone is laid back, and while you are still expected to perform, they don't over manage you at all.  So glad I took this job.
cons: Glassdoors requires five words for cons.

headline: Great exciting company with lots of potential
pros: I love working here. The other engineers are great to work with. The pay is better than any other offer in Utah county. They are a fast growing company with still TONS of potential to continue to grow. They are very transparent in almost everything they do. They have great perks - free food/soda, Sundance corporate passes, company parties every couple months, swag gifts. At the same time, it's not a walk in the park - they expect a lot from you.
cons: I honestly can't think of anything.

headline: Career launching startup!
pros:
There is a lot to consider when you are thinking about joining a new company. New jobs can cause a lot of stress, and there are high consequences if you make the wrong decision. Here are the questions / answers that went through my mind when joining Qualtrics:

1. Will I be challenged / work on hard problems?

Qualtrics has no shortage of hard problems. From distributed data collection to advanced analytics and data visualizations, Qualtrics has enough challenging problems to entertain most engineers. These challenges combined with Qualtrics' amazing growth present numerous career opportunities.

2. Will I learn / be mentored by other smart engineers and leaders?

This was a serious question of mine, and one of the main reasons I left my previous job. We are all capable of learning on our own, but when we are surrounded by top talent we will learn much faster! Qualtrics engineers are smart, and leadership is top notch (Amazon, Google, etc). It is rare to find a company where access to this level of experience is so abundant.

3. Will I be compensated fairly?

Of course this goes through everyone's mind. Qualtrics definitely pays competitively and is actually the most transparent company I have experienced with regards to the promotion process and pay increases.

4. Will I fit in with the company culture?

This is a personal question, but if you are wondering, come check it out. Qualtrics is very much a startup culture with a bunch of smart creative people eager to make their customers happy. In addition, it is family friendly, and people frequently have lunch in the office with their spouses / kids. Utah in general has a strong LDS culture; however, as a someone who is not LDS, I can verify that there are plenty of people who will be interested in grabbing a beer with you after work ;)

5. Will I enjoy where I am living?

This was an easy question for me. I personally can't imagine a better place to live. Utah has quick access to world class skiing, biking, and other incredible outdoor activities. Pair that with a relatively low cost of living and family friendly environment, and what more could you want? (Maybe a few pubs? Yes, Utah has those too!)
cons:
1. Hard to keep up with growth / expectations

Qualtrics, like any startup, has to run fast to stay ahead of competition and continue growing. At times this creates a lot of pressure on engineering to deliver customer facing value. This can be hard to do when also having the goal and responsibility of maintaining a healthy level of technical debt.

2. Commute for people from SLC or PC is ~60 minutes each way

It seems that most people moving to Utah tend to settle in Salt Lake or Park City. These are great areas, but they are also ~60 minutes from the office. Qualtrics helps by providing free transportation from both locations; however, a long commute is always hard.

3. Lacking in flexible work arrangements

Although Qualtrics has many perks, they are lacking in flexible work arrangements.  With so many tech companies competing for engineers, Qualtrics may have an easier time attracting top talent by offering a more flexible work schedule.

headline: Hyper-growth company with a good culture
pros: Great culture.  Very fast paced.  Lots of driven and motivated young professionals.  Most of the leadership team has come from companies who experienced hyper-growth (amazon, google, ptc).  Great office with walking treadmill workstations, kitchens with free food on every floor, in house gym, dog friendly, AMAZING views of the mountains and close to outdoor activities.  Really interesting and challenging projects and problems to solve. Great benefits - medical premiums are fully covered, stock options, and regular bonus'.  Utah is gorgeous (I relocated here for Qualtrics).  Not being Mormon I had some worries moving to Utah given the stereotypes but I have had no issues. Nobody has tried to convert me, I don't have six wives, and Utah has some of the best breweries.
cons: No 401(k) match.  Hiring so many new people its sometimes tough to know who you need to go to - so everybody goes to the dept head and bogs up their calendar.  Location can be a detractor for top/experienced level talent so most hires are right out of college creating a gap between entry and execs.

headline: (SALES) Most challenging experience to date - but most rewarding
pros:
1) Great products to sell/support
2) Awesome internal trainings to continue to improve individually 
3) Automatic promotions based on hitting identified goals (management is looking for internal leaders because the rate of growth is fast)
cons:
1) Sales expects a lot right out of the gates - nothing is handed to you and management wants you to prove yourself
2) You need to learn a lot fast (if you're uncomfortable with that - might not be the place for you)

headline: One of a kind opportunity and company!
pros:
There is a lot of room for advancement if you work hard and prove to be successful. If you do well you are recognized for that work. 

The company maintains a very transparent work environment so you always feel in the loop with whats going on!
cons: You will not move up unless you work your hardest and show that you are capable of the job!

headline: I can't ever see myself leaving!
pros: Amazing culture- golf carts, 4 fully stocked kitchens, massage chairs, treadmill desks, and basketball hoops around the office. No one has their own office so you have great access to the executive team. You won't be micromanaged and will be allowed the freedom to innovate and prioritize. It's amazing to be part of a company that is growing exponentially.
cons: The icecream can run out by Fridays sometimes.

headline: Qualtrics can't be beat!
pros: Qualtrics is an extremely special company! They absolutely live up to everything they claim to be. Working at Qualtrics has propelled my career 100 X faster than any other company could. I have had opportunities to take on more responsibility and learn faster than I even thought possible. They claim to still have the start-up mentality and it is absolutely true. If you value having autonomy and being able to take creative liberties in your job, then there is no better company than Qualtrics. The growth of the company means growth in my own career. The best part may be the individuals who work there. Everyone is an A player and has the same drive for success. Incredible leadership team who is accessible by anyone at anytime. At Qualtrics a motto is "we do hard things" and it is true. If you want to be successful, you have to be willing to go the extra mile. Excellent benefits and cover 100% health premiums for employees and their dependents.
cons: They do not currently match 401K plans because they cover the cost of health premiums. It would be nice to have that option.

headline: Better Than I Thought It Would Be
pros: The people from the bottom up are fantastic to work with. Qualtrics has done a great job of hiring top-tier talent, so you know the common denominator is someone who is intelligent, has drive, and who is willing to lend a hand to those around them who need training or help.
cons: They can't yet compete with the remunerations of more developed B2B companies like Adobe. However, with the new infusion of cash, I'm hoping for a compensation overhaul for most sales people.

headline: The best place to solidify your career
pros: Qualtrics is the best place to learn and build a solid professional background. Qualtrics is not an easy ride, so if you are looking for a place to sit back and relax, then go work at a calling center. You wear many hats at the company, so your learning potential is huge. As an account exec. you can work really close with product development, marketing, relationship management, etc. So can definitely build a solid background in the tech. industry. The company believes in you. They invest so much in our professional development with 3rd party consultants. I like that Qualtrics is a rare startup in the valley. A place where you can become a founder, not just an employee.
cons: Like any other young startup, we have our challenges. As a sales person you start at a low starting salary, and it takes a few months to get you ramped up. The company knows this, and has developed a new hire bonus program to reward hard work. Also, the benefits are sweet!

headline: If you are good, you will love this company
pros: For those that excel, you can earn promotions every 6 months. The leadership team deeply cares and works hard to help you earn your next promotion. The people you are surrounded by will be top notch. It is rare to look to your left or to your right and not be impressed. The compensation is incredible because there are comp plans from 50k a year to over 300k a year all based on your promotions and performance. It is all up to you and no amount of politics will hold you back.
cons: If you are looking for a job to just coast in, stay far away from this company as everyone is going a million miles an hour looking to make the news not just share the news.

headline: Great for Some
pros: Good starter job as a student or fresh out of school
cons:
Qualtrics is a rocket ship. There are unfortunately only a few at the company on board.

Gimmicks like free soda can't make up for low pay and menial responsibilities.

headline: Great Company
pros: Start Up Company.- a lot of opportunities everything is new and possible. Hard workers only. If your are not looking for a challenge please don't apply.
cons: Start Up Company.- you have to do differents rolls. Everything is changing and adjusting. There is no written rules. You ask for cons? Well I have none.

headline: Great product, great people, great job
pros: The company culture at Qualtrics is sublime, the founders really try to make sure that employees will fit within the culture. The free insurance, free food, free perks and amazing people really help this company stand out. Oh and the product is amazing too
cons: There are some office politics, however, I think if you work hard it'll get noticed and you'll end up in the right place

headline: Chaotic Good
pros: Qualtrics has a great product, and I like the culture. The company is growing quickly and there's some great opportunity for advancement. I have a lot of respect for the founders and the CEO--I feel that they genuinely care about their employees and their customers. They go to great lengths to be transparent and self-critical.
cons: It can be pretty chaotic because of the hyper growth. Middle management is not great. There's also a real lack of mentorship.

headline: Great entry level job
pros: Fun environment, lots of great people, merit based rewards, good training.  Excellent business strategy and lots of exposure in the market with a superior product.
cons: Because everything is metric/merit based, you are entirely responsible for yourself.  Also, the company is based in Provo, Ut - and subsequently is predominately LDS.

headline: I can't imagine I'll have a worse experience during my professional career.
pros: I grew close to my colleagues as both all of us were getting screwed, this made us closer.
cons: Working at Qualtrics was the worst year of my life. First, in the interview I was told to not worry about the very low salary because I would be making more than triple that in bonuses if I performed. I performed over and over and no such bonus came. Management will lie to you, and this wasn't the only time it occurred. I was told "Qualtrics is like Google in the 90's", and what's crazy is this is there sales pitch to get employees to continue to work near minimum wage jobs. I was constantly harassed by my manager to the point where I almost took action. Whatever you do, avoid this place at all costs. The sole purpose of the cool building and free food is to disguise you from what's really going on, which is practically indentured servitude. Ask they what their turnover is and this company will speak for itself.

headline: Great environment, competitive pay.
pros: Qualtrics is a rapidly expanding company full of great leaders and a sweet work environment. They really want to keep you around. You are rewarded for hard work and encouraged to do better by your leaders and peers.
cons: I think the only con is that it is in Orem, UT, where the only thing really going for the area is the outdoor experience (and believe me, it's an awesome experience, but that's it).

headline: I love my job
pros: Qualtrics is a mentoring and collaborative atmosphere.  Truly a team effort.  The "extras" that Qualtrics provides the employees are above and beyond:  catered meals, free healthcare, the coolest swag....the list goes on and on.  It's exciting to be a part of one of the fastest growing SaaS companies in the world and the leader in this space.
cons: We are hiring so fast it is hard to know everyone.  Not really a con.

headline: Hook you in with flashy things but then treat and pay you crap
pros: You will have job security knowing that the company isn't going anywhere which can be nice. It's a young fun atmosphere. There coverage and health benefits are amazing and they have good fringe benefits. Free food and clothes throughout the year was a plus.
cons: You will be under a microscope daily no matter how well you perform. POLITICS POLITICS and more POLITICS is the only way you will move up in this company. There expectations for quota, daily metrics and such are not matched by their pay. The sales cycle for the product is 3 months minimum so you better have some money put away to live.

headline: Great product,
pros: Qualtrics has a great product, good food and they offer good employee perks like pool tables, ping pong, etc. They have grown their business on cheap labor which is one of the key reasons they are financially sound. Leadership is OK. Could be better. The employees and your peers at Qualtrics are awesome. That was my favorite part of working at Qualtrics where the people I was able to work with.
cons: If you weren't in early on, there is a great chance you wouldn't be going up the chain very fast and won't make very much money unless one of the owners has some interest in you. Be prepared to drink the kool-aid from management that everyone will make a lot of money, that you can't be successful unless you are Qualtrics, everyone will be millionaires, etc. If you get on the core leaderships side and they like you, you will get lots of perks.

headline: Great model and excellent upper-management -- poor and young lower-mid level management with sub-par entry level support
pros: Good office space and young crowd. Lots of intelligent people and pretty clear pathway to "promotions." Seems to be an excellent place for engineers and product-dev people. Strong promotion of company values. Excellent benefits make up for very below-market compensation.
cons: There is little to absolute zero training for incoming employees in the sales team -- very sink or swim. The mid-level management and sales leaders are all mid-20s to early-30s and while intelligent, generally lack the maturity and sobriety to handle large and diverse teams (hence the tendency to hire primarily white males, likely around 90% of their employees).

headline: Amazing Growth
pros: The culture is great, they give you a lot of food, great people with exception of some senior leadership. Free company breakfasts on thursday. They pay the benefits for all employees. Fun environment.
cons: The work/life balance can be really hard on sales. As with any tec sales job, it is all about the numbers. Micromanagement has been hard to deal with. I do better when I know what I have to do and do it and not be dragged into the glass to see what I have been missing.

headline: Incredible place to have a real career.  That is rare in today's market.
pros:
- Management/founding team cares about making something that lasts
- True meritocracy; If you work hard and make a real impact, you'll be rewarded very well.
- Product and market strategy is well-developed. People know what they need to do to "win" in the market
- Incredible benefits options. 
- Culture allows for taking a risk. Newest employees can try different ways of doing things without getting "squashed"
- Transparency from management team. Weekly and quarterly meetings are great for showing where the company is going.
cons:
- Too much food! ;)
- As with any growing company, some functions in the company become understaffed relative to the company as a whole.  This can put heavy pressure on the individuals in the group to perform more than their share for a time.  This issue has improved dramatically as the leadership team has evolved over the last year.

headline: Great company with rapid revenue & employee growth
pros: Great office culture with pool tables, Foosball, ping pong, stocked refrigerators, catered breakfast and lunches, bring your pet to work and other great office perks. They are very generous with insurance as well and really care about their employees.  Senior management interacts with all employees and you can easily talk to anyone in the company no matter what level they are at.
cons: No matching 401k offered. Often have to work longer hours. Because the company is growing so fast there is often changes in accounts that you work with.

headline: A lot of opportunities to learn
pros:
Work environment is very nice (free gym, food, lunch on Tuesday, Friday breakfast)
There are a lot of opportunities to learn new things.
cons: Emloyees are very competitive. Which can be a good thing but it's stressful sometimes

headline: Fun while in school. But not a career.
pros:
- young, fun co-workers
- tons of free food
- pays much better hourly than any (non-programming) campus job at $15/hr.
- great exposure to many facets of a company
- getting time off is never an issue
cons:
- no career path for someone with a hard science degree, which seems to be all they will hire as product specialists
- your starting salary will not adequately reflect the kind of degree and GPA you need to get hired as a product specialist
- consistently hold "parties" to catch up on support requests in the evenings or on weekends (which is not worth a $25 gift card or dinner or the t-shirt you'll never wear that says you survived the madness). you're not required to attend just like you're not required to attend basketball practice over Christmas break.

headline: Not what they promise to be
pros: Good co-workers, free junk food
cons: Work is repetitive and boring, compensation structure changes frequently, no transparency with stock options, changes are frequently made that screw over employees for the "good of the company"

headline: Extremely Rewarding Experience
pros:
-Very clear career paths
-Limitless opportunities
-Most employees are extremely motivated and driven. This pushes me to reach new limits
-The experience behind the executive team undeniably will take this company to levels not seen from a Utah-based company
-Family friendly environment
-The company truly is motivated in all situations to figure out a winning situation for employees and the company
-Very generous with the commission structure ( including accelerators), paying 100% of healthcare premiums, PTO from Christmas - New Years, often feeds the entire company, etc.
-Very transparent.
-The culture is very innovative and exciting
cons:
-Being around some employees who aren't able to hack it, and hearing them make false claims about a company who has nothing but the best interest for their employees in mind.

-Can be difficult to get up to speed quickly.  Once you do, it's very well worth it. The company is figuring out how to help.

headline: Product Specialist
pros: Barnaby (the white labradoodle ), great food, great building, great people. Amazing benefits. Free swag, iPad minis, and a lot other great accommodations. Gym, Ski passes, sports teams, etc.
cons: Pay is below average, there are lots of little lies that are swept under the rug. Little opportunity to move upward. Asked to work extra hours with little incentive on a regular basis. Not transparent; though the office walls are.

headline: Best choice I ever made was to take a career at Qualtrics
pros: Everyone you work with is incredibly driven with "A" player mindsets.
cons: Like anything that is worthwhile, you put a lot of time into this at the beginning. Need to be very polished/sharp to see early success.

headline: Great place... Great people... Great product!!
pros: Culture, work-life balance, promising company that is going places. Gives you the Silicon Valley experience in Happy Valley, Utah.
cons: Initial compensation, promotions (can get stuck in a position).

headline: Great Environment, great people, horrible compensation
pros: Fun environment, fast growing business, lots of free food, flexible hours, brilliant colleagues, the building is very nice
cons: There is little growth or routes to management, Most high up employees are external hires, they work you like crazy and you don't get paid what you could be getting paid at any other company, I was told a different initial offer than I was actually paid. You are not given clear assignments, employees are rewarded for quantity not quality.

headline: Love this company
pros:
I am not sure why there are so many employees who have had issues. I have been here for years and I absolutely love working here. I am a current employee and I feel like I am treated incredibly well. I love the fact that we have great benefits and having 100% of healthcare premiums paid for is incredible. It would take a lot for me to want to leave Qualtrics. Here is a laundry list of items I love
-pay - I feel well compensated
-benefits - mentioned above
-fantastic people - some of my best friends work here
-opportunity for growth and leadership - there is no shortage of opportunities to grow personally
-high expectations - I only want to be a part of something where everyone around me is as dialed in as I am. This isn't a "9-5" place.
cons: I personally can't see many cons to Qualtrics other than the fact that it is still in startup mode and we are scrappy. We don't always have the most formalized policies and sometimes when you run fast you trip. This personally doesn't bother me but for those who are looking for a very "corporate" environment I think you are looking at the wrong company. The last thing is that as you get started in sales at Qualtrics you have to be in it for the long term. You will see your paychecks increase overtime but it will demand a high work load and require you to invest in yourself and the company.

headline: Best job ever.
pros:
Great bonus program (disproportionately rewards the highest performers)
100% insurance premiums paid by company
Challenging, fast-paced environment
Incredibly smart co-workers and managers, lots to learn. 
Lots of free food and creature comforts (massage chairs, comfortable couches for meeting, kitchens). 
Company is moving fast and is willing to do what it takes to take things to the next level.
cons:
Part-timers don't get many of the perks that full-timers get (i.e. bonuses, paid time off, health insurance).. but this is pretty typical for most companies. 
Typical growing pains of a company going from mid-size to enterprise status.

headline: Good company. You're either a salesman or a programmer...little in between.
pros: Young atmosphere. Great company for a salesman. Plenty of fun activities offered outside of work hours.
cons: Quotas are held firm regardless of personal situation. Management expectations can be stressful. High turn over.

headline: Free soda and taquitos don't make up for indentured servitude and dead end career
pros: My co workers were great.
cons: I now know three people who have left and all of them, including myself, now get paid 50%+ more at all our companies. Qualtrics starts it's engineers off at 45K, yeah, 45K for an engineering position! In Quni they get paid 30K and are expected to put in 50+ hour weeks.  In the year I was there not one person got a raise, and I know people who were there 2+ years and they were still making the same 30K they were when they started, with no additional skills. Management will lie to you, they've been talking stock options for over 8 months and they've promised about 3 times now they'll have them by the end of the month, still nothing. Turnover rate is crazy high because of the reasons I've listed. Please don't get blinded by the soda and the dog running around, you spent your time in College to get a good job that you could progress in, this isn't it.

headline: Excellent start to a technology career.
pros:
-Awesome leadership team
-Great culture, young crowd
-Sell to CTO's, CEO's, Deans, etc at a young age
cons:
-Low salary with inflated promises of commission earnings
-No clear picture of employee equity
-Boring after a while (was in sales)
-If you're destined to be a rock star in your career, you're too late in the game to be a key player at Qualtrics.

headline: They aren't what they claim to be
pros: Free food, healthcare coverage.  They have defined a somewhat transparent culture which is positive and the Founder is genuinely looking out for the employees.
cons: It is one of the most "bro" companies I have ever been a part of.  Individuals in management positions are constantly looking out for their "buddies" and pass them hot leads, good accounts and commission opportunities consistently.  That is about the only thing they are consistent in.  Other than that, they make special exceptions on certain protocols to benefit those they support and/or want to succeed.  Ever read the book "From Good to Great?"  They are good at best.

headline: Fun place to work
pros: The culture is fun, your coworkers are great
cons: A little informal and unstructured at times

headline: The fairest shake you will get in your career.  Seriously, go somewhere else and then get back to me.
pros: Transparency.  Upward mobility for those who perform.  Dynamic culture.  Exciting growth opportunities.  Very good leadership with people who are passionate about making a difference for both clients and employees.  The culture is unlike any other that I have seen or heard of.
cons: The hiring bar is set very high which may be frustrating for some (very selective).  The compensation structure is set to highly reward those who achieve, which can leave those who don't (and sometimes those ramping up) with an unpleasant experience.

headline: Great place for hard work and opportunity
pros:
Lots of opportunity - Does not come quick and easy but 100% available to those that work for it
Great learning experience as the company is growing so fast
Great people, especially if you are friendly and not entitled
Top of the line product and client list
cons:
Takes time to build experience and pipeline - this is a positive if your looking long term
Occasional growing pains of a billion dollar start up (good problems to have)

headline: Qualtrics is a Rocket Ship!  Just get on!
pros:
Career advice from Eric Schmidt, Executive Chairman at Google: 

"Get on a rocket ship. When companies are growing quickly and they are having a lot of impact, careers take care of themselves. And when companies aren’t growing quickly or their missions don’t matter as much, that’s when stagnation and politics come in. If you’re offered a seat on a rocket ship, don’t ask what seat. Just get on." 

Qualtrics is a rocket ship. The opportunities here are unbelievable.  It is such a dynamic workplace.  As the company grows, things are constantly evolving and improving.  The ability to pivot and grow is a must.  There's never a dull moment on the job at Qualtrics.

As an employee, my contributions are valued and my successes are noticed and rewarded.  Management is excellent - from team leads up to the founders.  They are passionate about Qualtrics and want their employees to be successful.  The people I work with are fantastic across the board.  I love coming to work.  

This is a great place to begin or to grow your career.
cons: I only wish I had started here earlier!

headline: Big Growth & Big Opportunities
pros: Great senior leadership that genuinely cares about the success of their employees. Industry-leading products. Fast-paced environment. High calibre people everywhere. Both the company and employees have great trajectories.
cons: Like any high-growth company, Qualtrics has had some growing pains but the company works hard to address problems head on and continually improve.

headline: Plagued with favoritism
pros:
Free food
Great employees
Fast-paced environment
Valuable experience
cons:
No transparency
Hiring all leadership externally
Very heavy favoritism
A lot of lip service

headline: Great Company
pros: Wonderful people, awesome product, and great opportunity. Perks include lots of fun swag, food, and top of the line health plan. The culture of success, get it done, and own it is also appealing.  If you like high rewards for smart and hard work you will like Qualtrics.
cons: Initial start up for sales can be slow until you build your pipeline, but they compensate you with other numbers and bonuses that are very achievable.

headline: Good not Great place to work
pros: Has some nice perks like nice work place. Free food. Enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons: Left out some basic benefits. No payment matching for 401k. They are still trying to get there act together on the development side of things, but they are making good progress.

headline: Fun place to work. Fair share of frustrations.
pros: Qualtrics provides a fun atmosphere, lots of free food, mostly good people who like to work together (and are obsessed with college football), has mostly decent upside potential IF you plan on being there for several years. This is a great job if you want to be a career salesperson if you're viewing it as a stepping stone to a real career.
cons: They're not as transparent as they say. Some shady stuff goes on. Most people drink the kool-aid for a year or two before waking up and realizing it's not quite as amazing as they were led to believe.

headline: Underpaid, overqualified.
pros: Great culture. Cool people. Lot's of Microwavable Food.
cons: Here's the deal, if you aren't concerned about getting paid well and only care about cool "perks" and showing your workspace off to friends/family, Qualtrics is great. They distract you from how bad your salary is with cheap perks, like microwavable food and swag. Salaries are hidden very well and odds are someone who came in after you with less qualifications is getting paid more. Management isn't looking out for your best interest. Their main job is to get you to work for as cheap as possible. This is fantastic if you're on the board of directors or in upper level management. Sadly, for regular employees, this is terrible. There isn't a place in Utah County with more over qualified employees for what they do and get paid. I know personally three people who were promised that if they worked hard that after bonuses they would be making 85k+. They all turned out to make less than 40k. Jared will lie to you in interviews and misinform you on potential earnings, but it works because you go in believing if you sacrifice for the Q you'll get rewarded. At the end of the day you don't and only the company wins.

headline: The best company I've every worked for!
pros: AMAZING culture. Complete transparency. HUGE perks (multiple fully stocked kitchens, catered breakfast every Thursday morning. Subsidized lunch on Tuesday. Games throughout the office. Onsite gym. Amazing Christmas and summer parties. Q Swag every summer and winter)
cons: Honestly nothing. Sales can be tough, just like anywhere, but Qualtrics makes it worth while.

headline: Truly one of the worst years of my life...
pros: -I made many lasting friendships with coworkers
cons:
-Perks like food, prizes, etc are thrown in your face so that you'll forget how little money you're making and how badly you're being treated.

-The salary trajectory given in the interview is only for the best sales people who started at the very beginning of the company. Otherwise, it's not actually achievable.

-Mid level management is very misguided--I was given a hard time for conversations with co-workers and taking lunch breaks. Very unprofessional in meetings as well----individuals are berated publicly and called things like 'loser'.

-The line between work and religion is completely blurred. It is assumed that you're Mormon and you are looked down on if you do anything 'out of line'. Church things are constantly talked about it public and we were often told in sales meetings that we should be make sure to say our prayers near the end of the quarter.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to add value.  Company is growing very quickly and there are many places to take on projects you wouldn't touch in years in another organization.  Great management who care about you and have a strong vision for the company they personally execute on.  High performance culture that's contagious in all the right ways.
cons: Role and compensation growth are not clearly laid out making it seem more risking to start a career at Qualtrics.

headline: Can be easily tricked
pros:
Fun work environment
Free snacks/food on Fridays
Occasionally receive free stuff
cons:
Low pay
Very poor mid-level managers
Starting to hire everyone from the outside
Have a hard time keeping employees for more than a year or two because of pay and job skills. If you like making cold calls all day, everyday, this is the perfect job for you! (especially if you just graduated with a Bachelors degree)
Management keeps all of the money
Employees blinded by incentives (a $350 iPad mini in return for a $5,000 salary cut)
Losing core values as the company grows

headline: Qualtrics has created a fun environment and culture in the workplace.
pros: Fun people and fun environment
cons: Salary can be low depending on the position

headline: Qualtrics is going places
pros: Great company that is going places for sure! They will be a commonly known software for big business and research companies. They are growing like crazy and have a great environment where people want to be even when they are not working.
cons: First 4 months or so is tedious and can be frustrating as you build up your client base and learn the software.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Opportunity to work with top companies
cons: Hard work, but what job isn't?

headline: Transparency in all they do in an encouraging, learning-orientated company
pros:
Room for growth
Dynamic workload
Ease of access to leadership and your voice is always heard
Amazing culture created by the employees
cons:
We are all new to being a big business and some things slip through the cracks.
There are no other cons unless you are looking for a consistent job description and title. The Qualtics culture is based off of owning ideas and creating your own results.

headline: Great Product...Still learning
pros: Fantastic software.....by far the best survey platform in the world
cons:
Leadership is very arrogant and refuses to compensate anyone other that engineers and sales.
Free cereal, office bikes and pizza fridays are all tried into your compensation

headline: A company on the rise.
pros:
Early promotion opportunities
Flexible working schedule
Decent pay for entry level
Respectful upper management - they will actually listen if you have a concern.  If you own it, there is a good chance they will support you in making change.
cons: The company is still trying to figure a lot of things out leading to a semi-unsettled environment.  Definitely going through some growing pains.

headline: This company has given me more growth opportunities than I could have imagined!
pros:
Great Pay Upside
Incredible promotion opportunities
Very intelligent workforce
Very Friendly/Non cut throat environment
cons: Most employees, including myself, start around 7am and it is hard for me to get up.

headline: Qualtrics pushes you to become great.  One of the best work environments I've seen.
pros: Qualtrics gives you everything you need to be successful, without micromanaging you at all times.  The moto is work hare, play hard; which I think is extremely fitting for the company.  Prepare to work harder than you ever have before, and the reward will be worth it.
cons: There is a very high learning curve, which they give you every opportunity to achieve.  Salary is low compared to some other sales positions; however, the opportunity for growth is outstanding.  If you can make it through the first year then the financial success will be much higher.

headline: Great up-and-coming company with some growing pains
pros:
Fun environment
Flexibility
Opportunities for leadership & moving around positions
cons:
Flat structure
Easy to get overlooked
Hard to get people to actually listen to you

headline: Cool Company
pros: Cool work place. Good company trajectory.
cons: Promote ultra transparency, but a lot of the decisions that impact the company as a whole come out of nowhere.

headline: Great
pros:
Growing Very Quickly
Great Culture
Opportunity for Leadership
Generous Commission/Bonus PLans
cons: Currently no offices outside of Provo

headline: Great company!!
pros: Great product, fun environment, fantastic colleagues and a lot of opportunity. There is room for improvement in some areas of the company, but what company doesn't have that?
cons: For sales you have a low starting salary. The first months are difficult and most of the time minimal return because you are selling B2B which has a longer sales cycle.

headline: Very fun work environment.
pros: Free food, fun co-workers. highly skilled co-workers, fun work environment, self monitored work environment.
cons:
Highly over qualified sales team that is very underpaid. 
Product is good but really difficult to sell with the competing market. 
If you go work at Adobe or other software companies in the area your base pay alone will most likely be higher than your salary+ commissions. 
Way over crowed sales team, and the system used to track contacts is cluttered and broken.

headline: Good
pros: Cool Culture for the employees
cons: There really aren't too many departments

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Full of interesting people.  You can make a lot of friends working there.  The product is very impressive and sells itself.
cons: If you want to make a lot of money there you either have to be a software engineer or a really good salesman.

headline: Cool company, horrible sales plan
pros: The software is cool and exciting.
cons:
Comp plan sucks big time and the managers lie to you and make it sound like you will make more than you actually will.  I have been successful in every other sales job, but even with good deals at Qualtrics, there is little money to be made.

The sales territories are also a complete mess and there are several cut throat employees who do shady things!

headline: I absolutely love the work/life balance, compensation, benefits, and day to day activities working at Qualtrics.
pros: Qualtrics provides a very transparent environment throughout the company.  The compensation plan is great, they believe in a work/life balance, and are extremely goal oriented.  Those that accomplish their goals are rewarded.  I love the people I work with in the office, and the the clients I work with on a day to day basis.
cons: Qualtrics only promotes based on performance.  For me this is not a downside, but for others that feel they are entitled to promotion based on tenure, this can be difficult to swallow.

headline: Not easy but certainly worth it.
pros: The reason I left a large company I was working for to come here was the opportunity for growth.  When I start the company was very small less than 40 employees.  The compensation in regards to salary was tolerable, high than a lot of places but that is not where my money has been made.  My money has been made with a very aggressive commission structure.  There are clear cut and achievable ways to move up in the management and there are no limits on the number of managers the company can have.  Moving up in the company is totally based on you and no one else.  We are growing everyday and continue to expand new space in our building for the next generations of employees.  We hire amazing people with a multitude of talents.  The money is great.  It takes a few months to build up a pipeline so that you are making 80k+ a year but once you have done that you can easily grow and sustain that income year over year.
cons: The only downside to working at Qualtrics from some points of view would be the low starting salary.    It is high considering the role you will be in but where the real money is made is in what you sell.  It takes several months to build your pipeline and beginning closing deals, once you have done that you are closing deals about once a week.  It is not an easy job in terms of the challenges you face day to day.  You get out of it exactly what you put into it.

headline: Dynamic job where I have never at one time been bored.
pros: The opportunity to sell a product which is the industry leader in its market. Fun, friendly, and competitive work environment. A job where I am stretched everyday and leadership opportunities come off of performance and not tenure.
cons: Well, honestly it is very hard to think of any downsides. About the only downside I can think of is that Qualtrics does not match 401k.

headline: The best job I have ever had!
pros:
As a college student nearing graduation I was surprised how much of a chance I was given by Qualtrics.  I was never discriminated at based on my age or work experience.  From Day 1, I was able to control my salary, my position and my happiness on the job by how hard I worked and how much success I saw.

While the sales process is very demanding and at times stressful, the corporate environment is far more fun and relaxed.  Sports tournaments, company lunches, clubs and groups are common in a very fun and modern work environment.

At the end of the day, I can think of many jobs where the owners know everyone personally by name and I couldn't think of a better place to work.
cons: The pressure to close is very high.  You're expected to succeed and earn your worth at the company.  If you're not competitive and driven, chances are Qualtrics sales won't be a good fit.

headline: A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.
pros:
It is very clear what you need to do to succeed and make a lot of money.
The people you work with are successful, ambitious, intelligent, and friendly.
The company is financially secure and experiencing explosive growth.
The founders promote from within, giving everyone a level playing field for moving up in the company.
cons: Working at Qualtrics and succeeding is one of the hardest (and most rewarding) things I've done in my life. You are surrounded by impressive people and you have to push yourself to the limits to stand out above the crowd. For some people, they might see it as a con because you can't just clock in and clock out - but if you are ambitious and hard working, it means there is amazing opportunity for you at Qualtrics.

headline: Incredible opportunities, Great culture
pros:
Opportunities for growth and leadership that you can't find anywhere else. 
Fun and unique culture (Very Google-like)
No earnings-ceiling, potential for a great income
Catered lunches
Flat organization
Great benefits (Incredible offices, paid vacation, health/dential/vision/401k, etc.)
cons: The sales teams are a very competitive group, so you must be extremely self-motivated, focused, and driven to stand out.  You will need to put in more than a 9-5 to succeed at Qualtrics, which is great for some, but wouldn't be ideal for those seeking a set schedule.

headline: I love my job, my co-workers, and the environment
pros: Qualtrics provides a great flex time off of 13 days a year, plus 7 holidays off, in addition to an average of 2-3 weeks off a year for Christmas. When you combine that with that most employees make well over 60k in sales after they have been there for two years the upside is great. Probably my favorite part of the job is how quickly the company is growing giving so many opportunities to grow with them and take on roles that matter.
cons: The only disadvantage I see is that we only have one office. I would like the opportunity to work for Qualtrics but have the chance to move to other offices for a while. However, I have heard they are thinking about opening other offices so stay tuned on that.
